  4417. Love the small charger!!!

  4420. I have sensitive teeth, so was a little worried; but so far no issues.
  4421. The other possible issue is that Braun's guarantee requires the consumer to pay shipping to return the toothbrush if it develops problems, whereas Norelco sends you a new one with a postage-paid label to return the defective one.

  3. Exactly what I wanted at a reasonable price. I don't know why anyone would pay more for an electric toothbrush. It occurred to me that if my dentists have always used small round rotating brushes (vs. any other motion), then that must be what's best and therefore what I should use. And any electric brush is better than a manual when you consider how many more strokes it produces in the same amount of time.

  11. I purchased this toothbrush after reading several reviews that this brush is the best combination of effectiveness and price. I've been using mine this last month and have noticed my teeth to not only feel cleaner, but to look it as well. They look whiter and shinier than ever. In addition, I've notice a little bit of gum re-growth in a spot where it had receded. I was hoping this would be the case, but I wouldn't have blamed the brush if this didn't happen. However, it has, and I couldn't be happier with this brush. Not too expensive, but it still offers all the results of top-tier brushes. It may not have all the bells and whistles, but it has (as far as I can tell anyway) all the performance. Highly recommended!

  24. I bought this Oral-B electric toothbrush to replace the old one I have been using for the past 15-to-20 years. If the old one is any indicator of the new one's durability, then I should be using my new one for a LONG time. In fact, the only reason I needed to replace the old one was because the plastic \\"keys\\" on the handle which slots on the brush unit \\"keyed\\" into had worn down over years of daily use. As a result, the brush unit itself turned a little when in use, not just the brush wheel. I've now used my new one (I got the Precision 1000 model) for over a week and am very pleased with it. The brush wheel oscillates quite a bit faster than it did on my older unit, making my teeth feel really clean. The replacement brush tips I had on hand for my old unit even fit the new one thus saving me the cost of having to purchase different ones for the new unit -- Oral-B replacement brushes aren't cheap.<br />If I had to come up with a complaint, it would be that the charging base is a little insubstantial resulting in it being hard to place exactly where you want it on a flat surface -- it's not heavy enough to resist the force of the power cord pushing against it. Also, the new charging unit does not have a place to wrap excess cord like the old one did; and, no, the new handle won't fit on the old charging unit. But those are minor flaws that shouldn't dissuade anyone from buying this toothbrush.<br /><br />Added 6/21/13: I forgot to mention it in my original review, but as \\"icing on the cake\\", although I ordered this item with Amazon's \\"free\\" delivery choice, I received it about 3 days after placing my order. Thanks, Amazon!

  49. Gets the job done!<br /><br />I have been a user of electric toothbrushes for the past 18 years. I started out with Interplak and used that for almost two years, until the battery corroded. I replaced that first electric with another from the same brand. Eventually, the Sonicare came out and I switched to that brand. That Sonicare lasted a very long time. Sometime around late 2005, I bought my first Oral-B. The Oral-B was one of their mid-end models and it also lasted a number of years. The nickel-cadmium rechargeable batteries were still working fine, but the charging base got damaged during a move. I replaced that one with a cheap model, also an Oral-B. This cheap model will only hold its charge for about 3 brushing sessions before you notice a significant performance decrease and the unit would need to be fully recharged. As they say, you do get what you pay for. There are times when you travel and have to take the brush with you. It would be nice to have something that will hold a longer charge. So, I bought this one. This one is much better than the previous Oral-B. It uses the same model of brush head but this model cleans more aggressively than the previous one. So, here we are, my sixth electric toothbrush in 18-19 years of use. Of the six models, I would say that the only ones that I did not like were the low-end Oral-B and the first Interplak. All the rest were good at what they were supposed to do. You do not need to spend 100+ dollars on a top-model like the Sonicare to get good results. I have found that the key to getting good performance is to replace the brush head often. Get the name brand brush head if you can. The brush heads on the Sonicare tend to last longer than the ones on the Oral-B, but they are also typically more expensive. It is your choice.<br /><br />I can easily recommend this model, the Oral-B Precision 1000, to anybody who wants to use an electric toothbrush. Spending more money will not necessarily clean your teeth better, in my experience. What you give up is more features, like UV sterilizing and perhaps additional cleaning modes (like a gentle cycle on your washing machine, some brushes have a mode for delicate users). My advice when it comes to electric toothbrushes is to avoid the low-end and the high-end. somewhere in the middle is the sweet spot. Get a model that uses the same brush heads as the higher-end models and you will get the same cleaning performance.ur teeth better, in my experience. What you give up is more features, like UV sterilizing and perhaps additional cleaning modes (like a gentle cycle on your washing machine, some brushes have a mode for delicate users). My advice when it comes to electric toothbrushes is to avoid the low-end and the high-end. somewhere in the middle is the sweet spot. Get a model that uses the same brush heads as the higher-end models and you will get the same cleaning performance.
  50. My first electric toothbrush. It cleans significantly better than manual, but is pretty loud.
  51. I love electric toothbrushes, they really get my teeth clean and shiny and I find that I brush my teeth a lot longer than with a manual brush ( which either hurts my gums if I brush too hard or I end up hitting them while trying to maneuver it in the mouth) and I like the small size, it's actually perfect. I also find that using gel toothpaste works best with this type of brush.<br /><br />This is a very powerful product, I had brushes that cost twice that and this one seems to put them back in tame territory, and that clean feeling is addictive, I always feel ready for bed when I use this, I also love how it comes with a charger, no batteries to mess and fumble with, easy and convenient.
  52. This is our family's second oral b. The first lasted for about ten years. The only option we had on our first was a 2 minute timer that let you know you had brushed long enough. This model 1000 was a great replacement for our original. No bells and whistles just a great toothbrush. My oral hygenist noticed a huge difference when we had to get rid of our old Oral B. Now I feel confident that I'm doing my gums a favor. As before a great product. I definately recomend it.
  53. This is at least my third Oral-b electric toothbrush, the first was a AA battery powered model that wore out mainly from a lack of waterproofing. The second had rechargeable batteries and ran for around $20 in 2003. It did well until the on off switch wore out.<br /><br />The first thing I noticed in Oral-b 100 Professional Care 1000 Electric toothbrush is the battery/ charge indicator. It lets you know when the toothbrush is charging, is charged, and needs charged. Depending on your daily use, it can go about a week with the low battery red light comes on.<br /><br />The brush head technology hasn't noticeably changed ]during these years. It does a good job of getting around and between teeth, though the small opening in the plastic casing means, saliva, toothpaste and water will all get in their, which can get gross, unless you rinse well and take the brush head off from time to time to rinse out the inside. I'm sure there is a reason for this hole, but I think it should go.<br /><br />Like most things, it comes down to personal tastes, but I found my [[ASIN:B0019ZGU1S Philips Sonicare R732 Healthy White Power Toothbrush]] does a better job of getting my teeth clean and has three speed settings. It does of course cost twice as much, but comes with a travel case and two brush heads.<br /><br />Overall, this Oral-B model is acceptable, though I question why it's so much better than some of its less expensive counterparts simply because it has a battery indicator and the word Professional in its name.
  54. Have had it only a few weeks but works great and half the price of my old one which was just like this one. Go figure.

  76. I went to the dentist after years of neglecting them and pretty much got the bad news of cavities and gum disease. The first thing they told me to do was get an Oral-B rechargeable toothbrush. This has been one of the best pieces of advice I've ever received. It feels like I have new teeth. I brush twice a day but even if I forget to brush one night, the next morning my teeth STILL feel clean. Of course I floss, water pik, and use mouth wash too but this brush has been the true game changer for me. And for the confused users out there, the pressure sensor does not turn the brush off. It stops the \\"3d\\" motion, which means the brush continues to spin but doesn't vibrate towards and away from the tooth. You can tell its activated because the brush will sound different. Either way I'd HIGHLY recommend this brush. I've only used the regular head that's come with it but I've heard the floss action is even better so its possible this brush may be even better than this.

  83. I have been using Oral-B electric brushes for as long as I can remember.<br /><br />Works well.<br /><br />The problem, and its a huge problem, is cleaning the brush. Rinsing thoroughly and shaking off water may seem all that is needed. It may look clean.<br /><br />Now try shaking the brush head vigorously. A lot of black slime will pop out. Looks like bacteria! After inserting a small stiff brush in every crevice I could see and shaking the brush head again, more black slime appeared. Well and truly shocked, I used a pulsating water aerator (water pik) just to see whether any more black slime remained. And indeed there was. Lots more. All these from a brush head that looked perfectly clean on the outside.<br /><br />If you are using an Oral-B brush head, it is almost certain to harbor a considerable amount of black slime.<br /><br />I can only speculate that the slime is generated by the moisture trapped in the many parts within the brush head.<br /><br />Rinsing and leaving it to dry will not prevent it. Neither will shaking the brush head vigorously clear all of it. The brush head needs to be redesigned. In the meantime, I would recommend flushing all the slime out with a water pik.

  93. After several weeks of use I've been pretty happy with this brush. I can't say as some do that it's like a dentist's cleaning, since the brush doesn't scrape off hardened plaque build-up, of course, and there are places between teeth no brush can get, but it's very good, leaves a nice smooth clean feel. It's definitely better and faster than my manual brush, easier on my gums, and the small brush head more easily reaches hard-to-reach spots. It has plenty of oomph and a solid, precise feel, better than some others I've tried. A charge holds for five or six days of moderate use.<br /><br />My only misgivings so far apart from cost (see below) are minor. The instructions recommend unplugging the charger between charges, which is a slight inconvenience, though that should probably be done for most chargers these days. There's a light on the brush that flashes red when it's ready to be recharged. It seems to still have a lot of power left when that starts happening, enough I've found to go for a couple more days at least. The feature that notifies me every 30 seconds and every two minutes how long I've been brushing, by making the brush stutter, is a mild annoyance, and can't be turned off. Some like that reminder, though.<br /><br />This kind of brush is a lot more expensive than a manual brush, of course, and replacement brush heads aren't cheap either. A brush head is expected to last about three months. Since it seems to be more effective, and cavities and other dental issues are even more expensive (and no fun to remedy), the cost may be worth it. Currently there's another package ([[ASIN:B000050FDE Oral-B Professional Care 1000 Power Toothbrush]]) sold at Amazon that has the same model number brush and comes with two different kinds of brush heads instead of the one head that comes in this package, and is cheaper. That model does look a little different, though, maybe a little bulkier in the handle, so it may be an older version. Judging from its reviews, which go back several years from when the model was called the 3D, it works just as well. (The 1000 model number replaced the 7400 model number which replaced the 3D number, all without any claim of being a new model, but no doubt there have been some updates to it over the years.)<br /><br />Amazon sells a lot of replacement heads that fit this brush (and there are several kinds of heads that fit). It appears from wading through the reviews that the cheaper ones are likely to be fakes, not true Oral-B parts, and that they may soon fall apart, with some risk of cutting the mouth. I suggest buying from Amazon directly, instead of from a third-party supplier through Amazon, or from a reliable brick-and-mortar store, to ensure you get the real thing.ack several years from when the model was called the 3D, it works just as well. (The 1000 model number replaced the 7400 model number which replaced the 3D number, all without any claim of being a new model, but no doubt there have been some updates to it over the years.) Amazon sells a lot of replacement heads that fit this brush (and there are several kinds of heads that fit). It appears from wading through the reviews that the cheaper ones are likely to be fakes, not true Oral-B parts, and that they may soon fall apart, with some risk of cutting the mouth. I suggest buying from Amazon directly, instead of from a third-party supplier through Amazon, or from a reliable brick-and-mortar store, to ensure you get the real thing.

  105. Bought as a replacement for an old electric toothbrush that quit working. I like this one. The action is effective but doesnt tear your gums up. It cleans very well and is comfortable to hold. Some people will like all the notifications it gives you when you've brushed for 30 seconds, two minutes, and so forth.<br /><br /> It's easy to clean and water doesnt get inside it. I like that the charging stand has a very small foot print, so it's unobtrusive on the vaniety. The unit holds a charge for at least a week when I travel, so I dont even take the charger along. I read a bunch of reviews and articles about electric toothbrushes when I was looking for a replacement for my old one, and I found that dentists and experts agree there is very little, if any difference between various types of motions in electric brushes. Electric works better than manual, since you tend to brush longer and correctly. However, spinning, thrusting, jerking, and whipping isn't necessary to good teeth and gum healh. This brush was recommended by more experts because it's effective and affordable. If you need the bells and whistles to be happy, have at it.<br /><br />For me, if the tool does the job and I can afford it, I'm in. I'll buy this again.
  106. If you're an average American, high-end electric toothbrushes and water picks have always been things you saw in movies on television in the bathrooms of the rich-the people who had good things that you didn't have.<br /><br />The Oral-b Professional Care 1000 (we'll call it, \\"the PC 1000\\") Electric Toothbrush helps to rectify that; it offers you champaign dental hygiene on something nearer to a beer budget; replacing the manual toothbrush's large, dense pack of bristles with a small, circular head that is better suited to accessing each tooth's surface and removing food particles at the gumline where the worst of the nasty, irreversible damage happens.<br /><br />Using different technologies and approaches, Oral-b's high-end toothbrushes like the PC 1000 improve your oral hygiene not only by having a stronger action than the cheap competition (including its own low-cost vibrating toothbrushes), but by encouraging you to change your brushing habits to optimize tooth cleaning and gum health.<br /><br />Brushing with it is such a different experience from using any ordinary, manual toothbrush, that just reading the instruction-sheet can leave you standing there staring as you wonder about the brushing habits you've had for a lifetime. Using it properly involves big changes in the way you do things.<br /><br />The first change is that brushing with the Oral-b PC 1000 is counterintuitive: the brush does all the work. The PC 1000`s head combines a rapid vibrating motion with a rotating action; you use it not by vigorously scrubbing back and forth against the wall of your closed teeth, but by slowly running the brush first over your gums and then over and around each tooth individually. This provides a different and much more thorough cleaning than the one that manual toothbrushes provide.<br /><br />Also unlike manual toothbrushes, the PC 1000, helps to keep you honest and following the advice of dental care professionals by automatically reminding you to give each quarter of your mouth equal attention for a total of two minutes.<br /><br />Every thirty seconds, a timer in the brush causes the brush to `stutter' in several pulses that tells you to go on to the next section of your teeth and gums, if you're interrupted, you can turn the brush off and it will continue the cleaning program from where it left off so long as it isn't turned off for more than thirty seconds at a time.<br /><br />That's what it does and how it does it. Oral-b claims that using the PC 1000 remove double the amount of plaque that a manual toothbrush can and that using it for fourteen days will help arrest or even partially reverse the progress of gingivitis. I can't tell whether this is true or not without consulting a dentist. I do know that I have brushed with it and felt it loosen and remove firmer food particles from between my teeth by brushing alone and that is just scary-as in scary good performance.<br /><br />All in all, I'm impressed with the Oral-b Professional Care 1000. It is simple to charge (plug in charging stand, put toothbrush on it) and, when used properly, it changes not only how you brush but your entire attitude towards brushing; while the cost of it is not much more than what you would pay for not too many of Oral-b's own vibrating manual toothbrushes.<br /><br />I like it. I wish they had made them at this price many years and many dental complications ago.total of two minutes. Every thirty seconds, a timer in the brush causes the brush to `stutter' in several pulses that tells you to go on to the next section of your teeth and gums, if you're interrupted, you can turn the brush off and it will continue the cleaning program from where it left off so long as it isn't turned off for more than thirty seconds at a time. That's what it does and how it does it. Oral-b claims that using the PC 1000 remove double the amount of plaque that a manual toothbrush can and that using it for fourteen days will help arrest or even partially reverse the progress of gingivitis. I can't tell whether this is true or not without consulting a dentist. I do know that I have brushed with it and felt it loosen and remove firmer food particles from between my teeth by brushing alone and that is just scary-as in scary good performance. All in all, I'm impressed with the Oral-b Professional Care 1000. It is simple to charge (plug in charging stand, put toothbrush on it) and, when used properly, it changes not only how you brush but your entire attitude towards brushing; while the cost of it is not much more than what you would pay for not too many of Oral-b's own vibrating manual toothbrushes. I like it. I wish they had made them at this price many years and many dental complications ago.
  107. It appears that Braun has become exclusively a saving company and they have are leaving Oral B to brand/produce the line of electric toothbrushes. The bottom of the toothbrush (in addition to \\"Made in Germany\\") is labeled \\"Braun\\". Why is this a big deal? Well my wife has had a Braun 3D Excel for 10 years and it has worked flawlessly. The Oral B 1000 is virtually identical - except it does not have variable speeds.<br /><br />A run down on the Oral B 1000-<br /><br />- Nice charging stand - the Oral B 1000 can be charged even if some water is present due to its non-metal-on-metal contact between the charger and the brush.<br />- Oddly, it is only 1 speed. I am not sure if there is a need for variable speeds, since I only use the high speed, but the Oral B 1000 only offers 1<br />- Nice rubberized grip<br />- Replacement heads are not overly expensive<br />- Not too loud - a humming sound is all that you hear<br />- Battery life - pretty decent - you take it on vacation without worries<br />- An efficient way to brush - the rotating heads really are more effective than standard brushing. This will help you remove more plaque from your teeth!<br /><br />Final Verdict -Whether you call it a Braun or and Oral B - the Oral B 1000 is a top choice for a moderately priced electric toothbrush.<br /><br />5 Stars

  111. Oral-b 1000 Professional Care 1000 Electric Toothbrush cleans teeth much more than manual toothbrushes. It's head gently pulsates to break up plaque and rotates to sweep it away, removing up to 2x more plaque than a regular manual brush . Oral-b professional care 1000 also helps improve gum health by helping to prevent and reverse gingivitis (according to Oral B). I can feel my teeth is cleaner and my mouth feels fresher compared to using manual brushes (kind of similar feeling after going to the dentist for regular cleaning). No brush can replace flossing however (so continue to floss). This tootbrush is rechargeable (come with the base) and very comfortable to grip. THe head is small enough to reach hard to reach areas and will surround and clean each tooth.<br /><br />Some drawbacks are: the brush is supposed to stop pulsating when you pressed too hard, but sometime you push hard and it doesn't stop and some other time you don't push too hard and it stop (i.e. not very consistent. the idea is great however). The battery is not replaceable (it's sealed, but probably for the better so water will not leak inside). Lastly, the brush head replacement is quite pricey.<br /><br />Sidarta Tanu

  114. This is my second Oral-B electric toothbrush, my first failed after years and years of reliable service because the battery could no longer hold a charge. This new unit cleans my teeth exceptionally well, is stoutly built, and should last at least as many years as its predecessor. The rest of my family uses the very prominent and considerably more expensive alternative whose name rhymes with tonic share. I tried to use that brand, but could never get used to the uncomfortable sensation it created in my mouth and gums, so I went with the Braun Oral-B. In the time I've gone through one Oral-B brush, my family has gone through 2 of the competitors. Switches failed or batteries wore out - requiring them to purchase expensive replacements while my trusty Braun kept reliably plugging along. I'm not saying they make a bad product, but the Oral-B brush gets your teeth every bit as clean, cost considerably less, and are more reliable and long lasting. In my book, that's a 5-star product.

  118. I bought this to use while I waited for Norelco to send me a replacement for a defective Sonicare (the second one to go bad, but Norelco has been good about replacing them at no cost). I was pleasantly surprised to find that it works just as well as the Sonicare, and even though I have my replacement, I'm still using the Braun most of the time. The Sonicare is quieter and has an auto shut-off that the Braun lacks, but the Braun's smaller, round brush head makes it easier to reach farther back in the mouth. They weigh about the same, but the Braun feels a bit more comfortable. The big drawback is the noise, but it's not enough of a problem to keep me from using it. The other possible issue is that Braun's guarantee requires the consumer to pay shipping to return the toothbrush if it develops problems, whereas Norelco sends you a new one with a postage-paid label to return the defective one. Still, for the money, this is hard to beat.

  131. I'm a big fan of the modern electric toothbrush - and so is my dentist! Properly used, these toothbrushes clean your teeth in all the hard to reach places (smaller brush head), and when gently held at a 45 degree angle near the base of the tooth, are excellent for removing the tartar that collects near the gum. I have been using the Oral B brand for years and years. I purchased an Oral-B 1000 to replace an older unit. Unfortunately, replacement is necessary after several years b/c the battery loses its ability to hold charge. Granted this might make the Oral B electric less \\"green\\" than an old-fashioned toothbrush, but in the whole scheme of things, I think it's a small price to pay for a life time of oral health. Apparently it is possible to replace the batteries if you're comfortable handling circuit boards and soldering guns (You Tube)...I'm not, but I promise to properly dispose of the old toothbrush! In any case, I love this new brush - it's more \\"powerful\\" than the old one and has a smaller footprint on the bathroom counter. So far, so good. Assuming it lasts as long as its predecessor, I heartily recommend this toothbrush!
  132. I've used an Oral-B electric toothbrush for years and only recently switched to the Oral-B 1000 Professional. The 1000 Professional is slightly smaller than my previous toothbrush and operates at a higher speed. I like the brushing action of the new brush for its tight and controlled feel in comparison to the previous one which seemed softer and looser with longer strokes. A single On/Off button on the handle controls the brush instead of the previous two. Both my wife and I find the button difficult to find by feel due to its small size, and a bit hard to press down. The one feature we could both do without is the quadrant timer. It is an annoying and unnecessary feature. It is only because of the On/Off switch and timer that I gave it 4 stars.<br /><br />Over the years, I have developed my own technique to keep the toothbrush fresh and clean. It is to run water over the brush and tip of the brush holder with the brush operating. Once clean, I remove the brush and run water over it and the tip of the brush holder, with the brush holder momentarily running. This cleanses both the brush and brush holder shaft seal. Once rinsed, I dry the brush and brush holder tip with a towel, momentarily running the brush holder as I wipe it dry.<br /><br />The Oral B-1000 Professional electric toothbrush is an excellent, quality product. Other models in that line have additional bells and whistles that for most people are unnecessary and therefore not cost effective. Whether you currently use an electric toothbrush or have never used one before, you'll most probably be happy with it.
  133. Died/not charging after less than a year/ 30-50 uses. AVOID!
  134. This is a really nice brush. I've never used an electric toothbrush before. I can really notice that it is working way better than my manual toothbrush.<br />I would recommend this product.
  135. I had previously used the Oral-B battery powered electric toothbrush (the $15 one that uses AA batteries). This toothbrush has much more power and cleans a lot better. I got this toothbrush for $29. Watch the price, it fluctuates a lot.
  136. Just what I needed - however I saw the same thing at Target for less.....
  137. This is my second Oral-B electric toothbrush & I have been very happy. My old one finally bit the dust after about 7 years of use. I liked the old one & I love this one also. The 50% rebate offered by Procter & Gamble made it a very good bargain. I definitely recommend this product to others.

  141. I purchased this to replace my previous Oral B Triumph (equivalent to the Oral B 4000 current model) that wore out after several years of use. I was happy with the Triumph which had an LCD display showing digital brushing time, tells when to replace the toothbrush head, charging status, etc. and also had 2 additional modes of sensitive and polish. Since I didn't find the digital info useful and always used the normal mode which was never a problem for my sensitive teeth, I decided to \\"downgrade\\" to the no frills Oral B 1000 model featuring one speed and no display. I am very satisfied with its performance and I like the slimmer handle and lighter weight.<br /><br />I had to go back to manual brushing while I waited for the Oral B electric toothbrush to arrive and there is a huge difference in the results. No matter how long and carefully I manually brushed, I could not achieve the thorough cleaning that I got with power brushing. It's definitely a difference in clean that you can feel and is impossible to achieve with a manual brush. I highly recommend this toothbrush.

  143. My first Oral-B was a Vitality which I liked very much and it served me well for over 7 years. I took a step up to the Professional and am very glad I did, it seems to do a better job, but I miss the 2 minute shut off that the Vitality had. I would definitely recommend this to a friend.
  144. I've had previous versions of this brush which have worked well over the years.. earlier units were basically the same but had multiple speeds and a large charging base to hold multiple brush heads, both of which I never used. Both were great at cleaning my teeth.. But this new model is simpler and just as effective.<br /><br />For me it's helpful this has just one speed setting.. on & off. This way I can rinse the brush and continue brushing without having to go through 4 button presses each time to stop the brush. You don't want to pull a moving brush out of your mouth because it will make a mess.<br /><br />Battery life is excellent, running 1-2 weeks between charges. The handle has an LED to indicator that blinks red when the battery is low.<br />The charging base is tiny and simple. Replacement heads are sold everywhere and are not expensive.. I get months of use out of a single head.<br /><br />My wife uses the Sonicare vibrating toothbrush, which I hate.. the buzz it makes in my mouth causes my skin to crawl! I'm skeptical as to the performance of Sonicare's vibrating head vs. a scrubbing head like the Oral-B.. I think the Oral-B cleans better and gets into the gumline as well.<br /><br />This Oral-B is highly recommended by me!
  145. Oral-B has a number of brushes available - the Sonic, Vitality, the Professional Care family (which comprises the 1000 and 3000), and the Professional Care SmartSeries (4000 and 5000). The Oral-B 1000 is the entry level of the Professional Care series.<br /><br />In my usage of the Vitality and the Oral-B 1000, the Oral-B 1000 stands at the minimum level of functionality to make an electric toothbrush viable.<br /><br />For example, the Vitality does not have a quadrant timer (it beeps only at the end of the 2-minute cycle), is rated at only 7600 oscillations per second, and does not have battery charging indicators.<br /><br />The brushes in the Professional Care series on the other hand add quadrant timers, and are rated both at 8800 oscillations per second and at 40,000 pulsations per second.<br /><br />As you go higher in the Professional Care family you get multiple brush modes (daily clean, sensitive, polish, deep clean), pressure sensors, and even wireless displays.<br /><br />Overall, the brush is simply wonderful. I've tried the pro white, precision clean, and dual clean brush heads, and I'm simply thrilled with each, though the dual clean head is my favorite. It works noticeably better than my manual toothbrush, in particular with cleaning between my teeth.<br /><br />I'm definitely a happy camper.<br /><br />Do note that the Professional Care 1000's specifications indicate the presence of a pressure sensor. Unfortunately this does not work on my brush - and given the experience of other reviewers - I'm inclined to think this is simply a misprint in the specs.<br /><br />Happy Brushing!
  146. Great brush though I don't have anything to compare it with since I am a first time user. Researched all others and for the price it's a great buy. I don't think I would have used all the bells and whistles that other brushes offered. This one is simple and straightforward. There is no room for other brush heads to be stored on the stand but this is not an issue for me since I am the only one using the brush. The precision clean brush head is not too hard or soft and does a great job. I have sensitive gums and did not find this brush head to be too abrasive.

  158. I have been using the Original Oral-B 3D Electric toothbrush for about the last 5 years and have been loving it before it finally died. I paid twice as much for the OLD version than I did for the new version 1000 model. The main differences between the two was that the old version had two speeds (which I never used the slower speed anyway) and a much larger base with storage compartments for additional brush heads. I am still using the original base with the new brush. The new brush comes with a smaller base with no storage which is all I would need anyway.<br />You could pay much more and get the more expensive models with all the additional bells and whistles, but do you really need them? They all brush the same way and give you the same good results.<br />The extras you pay for are things like an external timer that you can watch to see if your brushing long enough (BTW the 1000 model has timing intervals that are simply momentary pauses every 30 seconds), or Battery level indicators (I keep mine on the charging base all of the time, so the Level indicator would be useless to me), or a flashing LED if you are pressing to hard.<br />If you already know how to brush your teeth, all the extra's are a waste of money in my opinion.
  159. Replaced one we had for 10 years. This simple, one speed, auto stop with too much pressure is GREAT. Wish that this one came with the little adapter to hold two brushes, that would have made this perfect. But, well worth the price when you compare it to similar items.

  168. Consumers Reports Magazine rated the Oral B smart series (3000 and 5000) as the best electric brushes based on evaluation of users by dentists (using plaque revealing dies).<br /><br />The reason the 1000 was not as effective is because it comes with a standard head instead of the floss head like the smart series. The price clubs sell the 1000 series with the floss head.<br /><br />Trust me, if you replace the standard head with a floss head (same price for the head), you will get the same highly dentist rated results shown by Consumers Magazine at half the price. The extra thrills of the smart series will not be used by most consumers (sensitive and polishing cycles, feedback display, etc).

  189. I researched a lot of different options before ordering my first electric toothbrush, and I'm glad I went with this product. It has just enough features for me, and I like that the base of the toothbrush is wide enough to stand on its own. My husband ordered the Oral B Pulsonic Sonic Electric Rechargeable Power Toothbrush because it was slimmer, and he thought it would take up less space. However, it turned out to have a larger footprint because its charging base is so wide (around 2.5 inches compared to 1.5 inches for the 1000 model).<br /><br />I was stunned at how \\"fresh from the dentist\\" clean my teeth felt when I used this toothbrush. When I travel, I take a non-electric toothbrush and now find myself unsatisfied without an electric toothbrush. At first, I took advantage of the feature of the 1000 model that lets you know how long you're supposed to brush each quadrant of your mouth. The toothbrush will pause its normal vibration after a certain period of time, and you get a really thorough clean if you follow its lead. I admit that now I'm usually too lazy to brush for as long as I should, so I ignore the pauses.<br /><br />This toothbrush holds charge for a long time, so I only plug it in when the low battery indicator comes on. I have to clean the brush regularly because excess toothpaste foam drips down the brush and hardens, but I imagine that's an issue with any electric toothbrush.

  201. This is my first electric toothbrush, so some of my views might be misplaced, but I thought they would still be valuable to those also looking to make the switch from a manual toothbrush. The first thing I noticed was that the oscillating action of the brush is pretty intense. Combine that with the stiffness of the bristles and it definitely takes some getting used to. I still feel like I would like to have a lighter setting, but I think I just need to adjust to the different feeling.<br /><br />The other thing that is very different is the way is moves the saliva around in your mouth. The power action is constantly pushing the toothpaste/saliva out of my mouth and I keep drooling on myself! I had to lean way over the sink and just let the drool roll other wise I keep getting my shirts dirty because it drips right down on me. Again, just an adjustment thing, so I'll keep working to find a way to brush without forcing so much saliva past my lips.<br /><br />I do like the small, compact base. The charging light is green and flashes when being charged. Once the battery is full, the light stays off (which I like). The toothbrush also \\"talks back\\" when you push too hard. I notice that if I try to get too aggressive (like I'm brushing with a manual brush), the motor stutters on and off so you get the hint. Slow and gentle is the key to using this thing. Worn most of the way through the one brush head that it comes with, so I'll be shopping around for the best price on replacement heads very soon.<br /><br />Overall, I would give this product a thumbs up. Check Oral-B's website for mail in rebates too!
  202. This model is thin and light enough to be used by a 3 year old<br />It does not have the remote pressure sensor and smiley indicator as the highest end model but in terms of brushing works just the same
  203. This is my second Oral B electric toothbrush, and I've been very happy with both of them. The first one is a 3D Excel that I've used for over five years. The Professional Care 1000 is very similar to the 3D Excel. From what I can tell, it's primarily cosmetic changes - and the 1000 only has one speed instead of two on the 3D Excel.<br /><br />The level of clean achieved with these toothbrushes has been excellent for me. The amount of time that my dental hygenist spends cleaning my teeth is much lower since I started using the Excel. IMO, you can't go wrong with an Oral B electric toothbrush, and it really comes down to choosing a model based upon the features that you want. In the five plus years that I've used my 3D Excel, I have never used the second (slower) speed. I believe that the slower speed is for more sensitive teeth/gums, but the \\"normal\\" speed has been fine for me - and I have sensitive teeth and gums. So, for me, the single speed on the 1000 was just fine. I also found that I don't use the toothbrush head storage in the larger base of the Excel, so the smaller charging base of the 1000 was great. Based upon your preferences, you might decide that a model with multiple speeds or a base with storage fits your needs better.<br /><br />As a note - the different heads available can be quite different. So, maybe give a couple different versions a try if you don't like what comes with it. As an example, while I do use the normal brush speed, I prefer the sensitive heads because of my gums. The heads with the rubber disc in the center can be a bit abrasive to me.
  204. This toothbrush is extremely good. I was surprised that it actually made my teeth noticeably whiter after about 2 weeks. I chose the 1000 model as opposed to the more expensive because it is the same thing, except for a few things that you do not need. Who needs an LCD display when you brush your teeth? lol. I found this model for around $40 so i bought it and i'm extremely satisfied. The replacement heads are around $3-4 each so keep that in mind. Each charge lasts about 8 days before it tells you its low and you need to recharge and you would not want to go past that because the lack of power is noticeable at that point. It takes about 16 hours to re-charge and its recommended to completely run down the battery once a month to make it last longer. Before this brush, I used the cheap $13 oral b electric precision toothbrush that was made in china and it is nothing in power compared to this. I dont recommend that you re-charge it after every use because it will kill the battery much faster.

Even Wally world sells these for $39 + tax.<br />2)Cleans my teeth better than any mannual brush I ever had.<br />3)You can buy generic brush heads for $6.45 free shipping. I like these heads better than the OEM brush heads.<br />4)The charger has a small foot print so it does'nt take up much room on the counter.<br />5)I work on a boat and even in rough seas the tooth brush does'nt fall of the charger.I did have to velcro the charger to the counter.<br />6)Very easy to keep clean. A quick rinse and a wipe and that's it.<br />In sum I paid $44.65 for the tooth brush and a year of brush heads, cleans my teeth, easy to keeep clean, will not fall off the charger. Fits my needs totaly.
  226. I do like the product. It works exactly as intended and holds a charge very well.   229. I bought this toothbrush to replace my old Oral B Vitality electric toothbrush. I was looking at another toothbrush, but didn't want to spend a ton of money. Then I found this Oral B and I was thrilled to see it cost half the price and had the same amount of stars. The biggest reason I wanted to stick to Oral B was because I still had 7 brush heads that I bought for my Oral B Vitality which was gradually dying out. I was happy to find the toothbrush heads still fit a new model.<br />After purchasing this product and using it for about a month, I can say I'm still very happy with my purchase. I like the 30 second timer which tells me when to change it up. I also really like the little bit smaller version for this new toothbrush. The base itself is smaller, barely bigger than the toothbrush handle itself, and the handle is smaller as well.<br />I also tested the battery life when leaving it unplugged. On the packaging it tells you at home you can leave it plugged in without draining the battery, but &#34;for the environment&#34; they say it is also recommended to unplug it when not charging. I left mine unplugged for the first full week until it died completely (I don't think I even charged it all the way from taking it out of the box before doing this). I don't keep it plugged in regularly, but it can easily hold full power for a few days. Unlike the Vitality model it does not start slowing down before it dies completely, so if you travel regularly for more than a few days I recommend charging it completely before you leave.<br />I hope this product lasts a good 10 years like my last one!

  245. Decent toothbrush. I got it after my dentist recommended I used something mechanical to help with plaque build up.<br /><br />One thing to note is it does let you know when 30 seconds has past, it pulses oddly a few times, but it doesn't seem to time for exactly 30 seconds (comparing to myself and a timer). I'm not sure if the timing mechanism is off on mine.<br /><br />I have liked it so far though. If you are look for something with an audible beep or for something with gum care I would look for a more expensive brush. This one does have a few different brush options for sensitive teeth and gums, but only one speed setting.<br /><br />Overall a good intro to mechanical powered brushes for me, though I might go for something a bit more fancy next time.
  246. Great little electric toothbrush. I had an older version of this which eventually died. I love it.
  247. If you're looking to try a real electric toothbrush (not the Oral-B Pulsar cheapies), this is a good entry point. It gets the job done without a boatload of unnecessary bluetooth bells and whistles. I found that I needed to recharge it about once every two weeks or so.<br /><br />EDIT: To clarify, there isn't much point in reviewing the heads themselves because Oral-B offers several varieties. This comes with a basic head; I prefer the Flossing head but that's all personal preference.<br /><br />This brush features a timed brushing cycle with prompts to move to the next quadrant. When used properly (for the full duration and following the prompts) you get a clean superior to a manual and to a battery-powered manual electric (like Oral-B Pulsar, Crest Spinbrush, etc).<br /><br />The battery is NOT removable and cannot be replaced. I am finding that after about 2.5 years of use the battery is not holding a charge as long; I need to charge it twice weekly, now. I will eventually upgrade to another model.

  260. Have used the toothbrush for ~1 month now. Much quieter than the older Oral-B toothbrush I had been using (whose battery finally gave up after many years of use). I like the \\"quadrant\\" timer that provides a hint to move from one part of my mouth to the next. I charge it once per week overnight then put away the charger. The charge lasts for 2 brushes per day for a week. I recommend this product to anyone looking to purchase an electric toothbrush.
  261. There are no frills here--no extra attachments, no carrying case--just a tiny charger and a simple toothbrush with a single setting. If that setting had a label, it would be: 11.<br /><br />This is the loudest, most powerful toothbrush I've owned. And yes, it leaves you with that \\"just went to the dentist\\" clean, smooth feeling if properly used.<br /><br />On the other hand, a sonic brush, with its higher frequency, cleans about as well with less noise. And they're quite cheap these days; the [[ASIN:B0002M5JNY Oral-B S-200]] costs significantly less than this one. Both are sleek, well-designed units. I'm no dental professional, but I don't think it's wise to pay more for a toothbrush just because it has a little more raw power.
  262. I have used the Oral B Sonic Complete and the Philips Sonicare toothbruses in the past. This left my teeth feeling cleaner than both of those.<br /><br />I love the cup shaped bristles. They seemed to get down into the gumline better than the traditional shaped heads.<br /><br />The charging base is by far the smallest I've seen. A big plus if your counter space is limited.<br /><br />There is only one speed which isn't a huge issue. The only time I ever used the low speed on the Sonic Complete was when I first started using it and I had to get used to the sensation.<br /><br />The toothbrush gives timed signals to let you know how long you've been brushing. The speed slows down. It seems like the charge is running out but it's just to let you know how long it's been going.<br /><br />I would highly recommend this toothbrush.
  263. One speed and stops when you push hard so this brush is definitely easy to use. Might be especially good for kids and the elderly to keep them from hurting their gums. It can't be overdone.<br /><br />Make sure you put the paste on by pushing it into the brush and then insert the brush in your mouth before pushing the on button. The paste will just jump off the brush if you put a bit on top and turn it on. It really doesn't take much toothpaste at all for this small head. And you get a nice clean feeling mouth if you brush for the recommended two minutes.
  264. Can't beat the ultra cleaning this toothbrush provides and for the price, you can't beat it. Groupon had refills for cheap and you don't need to switch until every 3-6 months. Teeth cleanings are much easier with less pain at the dentist. You won't be disappointed.
  265. I am very happy with this toothbrush. It's my 2nd try at one of these and I love that there is a 'warning signal' if I am pushing too hard, which can hurt your gums. My 1st try was 10-15 years ago had no signals and I damaged my gum and had to have a graft...so now I feel I can get the benefit of the better electric toothbrush without worrying that I am not doing it right!
  266. I waited for over a month before doing this review because I wanted to see if this really works and I am glad to say that it does. My dentist has seen an improvement in my dental hygiene and my teeth feel and look cleaner.<br /><br />I have gotten more cavities than I should in the past. I will know six months from now whether I get less cavities but I am very hopeful that this will happen.<br /><br />The contents of the box are few and this product is easy to use. You get a charging base, brush head and brush handle. You connect the brush the handle and charge it and it is ready to go.<br /><br />The instructions suggest that you should brush your mouth in four quadrants and brush each for 30 seconds. The brush changes it vibration speed for a second or two after 30 seconds to let you know that you should shift to another part of your mouth. At the end of two minutes you hear and feel some more vibreations and you are done.<br /><br />If you brush too hard the pulsations stop. This is important to me since I have a lot of fillings and sensitive gums and I don't want to damage anything in my mouth.<br /><br />I will use a regular toothbrush on occasion if a tooth is hurting me or if it feels like the tooth needs more cleaning. This does not happen very often.<br /><br />The vibration feeling took a few days to get used to and my gums tingled at first. My gums don't tingle any more and I don't even notice the vibrations.<br /><br />My dentist feels the round head is better than ones normally found on toothbrushes. I know my teeth are cleaner looking.<br /><br />This is a simple product that works. I will try to update this in six moths after my next dental checkup.

  274. Update 4/10/12 - I just had my first dental cleaning after using the Oral B Professional 1000 with the Floss Action brush head for the last four months. The dental hygienist immediately said that it looked like I had gotten my teeth cleaned before coming to her to clean my teeth. When she was later scaling my teeth roots, she said they were smooth like glass. Although I still floss and use a Proxa Brush between my teeth before brushing with the Oral B Professional 1000, doing this routine after breakfast and supper, I've stopped using all the other electronic tooth brushes I used before. This one is all I need. I credit this excellent result to moving the brush very slowly for about 2 minutes per quadrant, not the entire job, for a total of 8 minutes, twice daily.

  276. Updated review with more detail to explain my 1 star opinion---<br /><br />As I've shared in previous reviews for Oral-B electric toothbrush products, one of the Oral-B \\"regular\\" electric toothbrushes (similar to this ORAL-B PROFESSIONAL 1000) that I bought a few years ago made my teeth sensitive to the point of having pain. My dentist, who had recommended the Oral-B toothbrush in the first place, diagnosed the Oral-B electric toothbrush as being to blame for taking the enamel off my teeth. This was a temporary condition that resolved on its own once I discontinued its use per the dentist's order. At that time under the dentist's direction, I went back to using a Sonicare electric toothbrush. However not much later, Oral-B came out with their first \\"SmartSeries\\" which has a special sensor that monitors if the user is pressing too hard on the teeth--this is indicated by reading the signals on an LCD display. My dentist then recommended the SMARTSERIES model.<br /><br />My husband and two children have been using the [[ASIN:B002HWS9GG Oral-B Professional Care SmartSeries 5000 Rechargeable Toothbrush]] for a few years. We own two units because my kids have their own bathroom. They all like the SMARTSERIES 5000. I like that it helps teach my children just how much pressure is enough and when it is too much. The dentist and I feel this helps prevent damage to their enamel due to erroneous use of too much pressure.<br /><br />The ORAL-B 1000 PROFESSIONAL CARE electric toothbrush product which I tested for Amazon Vine claims to stop pulsing if too much pressure is put on the teeth. I cannot detect any difference in action no matter how hard I push against my teeth. I also tried pushing it against a fingertip and the palm of my hand.<br /><br />In reading the directions in the box I got confused because the manufacturer is using one set of directions for multiple models of their toothbrushes but not being specific on the directions as to which model is in the box. I then turned to the box for a closer reading of exactly what the 1000 series could do. I found small writing on the back and one side to indicate this model has one mode brushing which they say is for daily use. In the direction packet it states other models have two modes, one for \\"daily use\\" and one for sensitive teeth that has less pressure. There is also a notation that some models have a tooth whitening feature (no model numbers are stated or I'd share them here).<br /><br />This model comes with one regular brush head. By close reading of the direction packet I learned there is another model of head that is for sensitive teeth.<br /><br />If you are shopping for an electric toothbrush you need to know there are many options on the market, even with this latest series by Oral-B there are different models, some with more options than others.<br /><br />Even though my dentist has never given me a diagnosis of having \\"sensitive teeth\\" I don't like the sensation of this 1000 series Oral-B toothbrush, it is very strong and since it doesn't seem to stop any action no matter how much pressure I exert on it, I worry it is too rough on my teeth. I plan to stick to using my Sonicare. My husband and kids are happily still using their SMART SERIES with an LCD panel that tells them if they are pressing too hard.r reading of exactly what the 1000 series could do. I found small writing on the back and one side to indicate this model has one mode brushing which they say is for daily use. In the direction packet it states other models have two modes, one for \\"daily use\\" and one for sensitive teeth that has less pressure. There is also a notation that some models have a tooth whitening feature (no model numbers are stated or I'd share them here). This model comes with one regular brush head. By close reading of the direction packet I learned there is another model of head that is for sensitive teeth. If you are shopping for an electric toothbrush you need to know there are many options on the market, even with this latest series by Oral-B there are different models, some with more options than others. Even though my dentist has never given me a diagnosis of having \\"sensitive teeth\\" I don't like the sensation of this 1000 series Oral-B toothbrush, it is very strong and since it doesn't seem to stop any action no matter how much pressure I exert on it, I worry it is too rough on my teeth. I plan to stick to using my Sonicare. My husband and kids are happily still using their SMART SERIES with an LCD panel that tells them if they are pressing too hard.

The flashing read light after use indicates that charging is needed and we choose to deplete the battery before recharge although this is unnecessary for good battery life. The brushing action is very good and better than our old brush. Personally I don't find the 30 second timer useful though this is good for those who brush in quadrants. Overall I find the Oral-b 1000 to be a well made, simple to use, and effective electric toothbrush.

  327. I bought two of these for my wife and myself. While they are most definitely better than any standard toothbrush, I find that I miss my old Sonicare. It could be that I am just used to the strength and feel of Sonicare, but this brush is quite a bit less powerful. This would be great for those people with sensitive gums who need to slowly work up to something more powerful, but for those of you who already owned an electric toothbrush I would get one a little more powerful.<br /><br />However, I really enjoy the feeling of the brush head on my gums and teeth. The swirly, vibrating head cleans great and massages the gums very well. So overall, I do recommend this brush as it does seem to clean well.
  328. This is my first electric toothbrush. I wanted to get one because I felt like my manual couldn't get my teeth as clean as I wanted, and my dental hygenist said that I had plaque around my gumline. This toothbrush definitely takes care of that problem. I think it might be slightly too powerful, but I'd rather go a little over the top than not powerful enough.<br /><br />I like how the head is small and you can pinpoint on locations around your mouth, except that I feel that it doesn't hold enough toothpaste. Other reviews have said that they like how you \\"don't need to use as much toothpaste,\\" but I think you don't use enough. I put toothpaste on it for one side of my mouth, and then stop and reload halfway through for the other half. It's inconvenient, but otherwise I feel like half my mouth gets jipped on the toothpaste and doesn't get as clean.<br />Another con that someone else mentioned--this toothbrush makes it almost impossible to keep from drooling all over. I have to lean over the sink in case I drool and usually stop one once or twice to spit while brushing to prevent it from dripping out of my mouth or ending up with a blue waterfall over my chin.<br /><br />I like how this toothbrush charges. When it's low the light turns red, when it's charging it blinks green, and when it's done charging it goes blank. Easy peasy. I also never felt the toothbrush losing power or become weaker when the red light came on to tell me to charge it.

I would've gave it 5 stars except for the lies!   359. I searched online for the best electronic toothbrush. It turns out, the style of this toothbrush has been found by Cochrane to be the only type of electronic toothbrush that outperforms manual toothbrushes when used as directed. Cochrane does meta-analyses and they are very conservative, which means that when they say something, it is pretty much true.<br /><br />I don't completely agree with their methodology -- one benefit of using electronic toothbrushes is that people spend more time brushing their teeth with electronic toothbrushes than with manual toothbrushes, so there's a decent chance that other electronic toothbrushes might, in the real world, outperform manual toothbrushes. However, their meta-analysis was toothbrushes, used as directed, and with that context, I believe them.<br /><br />Independent of my prompting, my dentist also recommended this very toothbrush, reinforcing my belief in its goodness.<br /><br />The one annoyance is that the internals of the toothbrush drain down, which creates a gunky toothpastey sludge at the base of the charger. The solution is to take the head out of the base after you're done brushing. That's annoying, but it eliminates the gunk problem.
  360. this brush is good. my dentist said my teeth look better after using it. It works. Pros: small footprint, makes mouth feel clean. Cons: long time to recharge, like 24 - 48 hours.

  394. My wife always says I brush too hard since my toothbrush heads wear out twice as fast as hers. When we got this, she thought that I'd finally learn that I was indeed brushing too hard. Well, either that particular feature is not working on this Oral B toothbrush, or I am brushing with the right pressure. I did try to really press down hard on it and it never did shut off. So I'm thinking I might have one where that feature isn't working. However, reading the other reviews, it sounds like others have gotten it to work.<br /><br />Other than that, this is a really great toothbrush. My teeth feel especially clean when I go through the whole 2 min routine. The toothbrush pulsates every 30 seconds to let you know it is time to move to a different quadrant of the mouth. Without that, I'm sure my brushing would only take me about 80-90 seconds.<br /><br />The charger is small and compact: it won't take much space up on your counter. I used to have an older model that had a wall mount kit. This does not have that, but that's no big deal for me. The booklet says the charge should last a week. This is a factor for me, since my bathroom doesn't have a convenient outlet for keeping this on the charger every night, so I have the charger in another room and only charge the unit when it needs it. In actuality, the red \\"needs a charge\\" light comes on probably about every 4 days (probably because I put too much pressure on my teeth).<br /><br />Overall, great toothbrush, with the best feature being the timed brushing cycle to ensure a really thorough job.
  395. Oral-B was offering a 50% rebate on all of its power toothbrushes so I figured this was a great chance to try out an alternative to the Sonicare toothbrush I had been using. Even without the 50% rebate the cost of the Oral-B models are lower than the Sonicare models. After doing quite a bit of research I also found that the only differences between the Professional Care 1000 and higher models like the 4000 and 5000 are the number of brush modes and unnecessary add-ons like timers and displays on the toothbrush itself. If your teeth are used to a good scrubbing there is no need to even use anything other than the standard brush mode.<br /><br />After about a week of use I found myself really missing the Sonicare technology. I didn't feel like the spinning bristles of the Oral-B were cleaning my teeth as well as the vibrating/pulsing bristles of the Sonicare.<br /><br />Oral-B used to make a sonic toothbrush called the Sonic Complete which still remains the best toothbrush I've owned. Unfortunately these spinning bristle models don't really do it for me and if you're used to sonic technology you will likely be as disappointed as I was.
  396. I like the Oral-b 1000 toothbrush. It does not seem to work any better than the less expensive Oral-b toothbrushes I have used in the past. The thing that I don't like is that the recharging light flashes while charging and really catches your attention at night when you get up to use the bathroom. I would probably look for a cheaper model Oral-b. Seems to hold its charge for about week but when the battery goes it is gone and you might have to finish with a manual toothbrush for that night. It has a light to let you know when to recharge but I ignore it until it gives out of power. It seems to run at a high speed all the way up until it stops, and that is good. I do not keep my Oral-b plugged in all the time and only plug it in when it needs a charge. I like the old Oral-b that would pulse to let you know that the two minutes were up. This model also has the two minute pulse alert but it has two additional ones at about 45 second intervals but are less intense than the two minute alert. It has so many alerts that you start to ignore them and might miss the two minute alert.

  419. The product information on Amazon is incorrect. This product can not use all the different brush heads, as stated above. Specifically, it cannot use the Ortho head, though it specifically states in the product info this is one that can be used. OralB's website says the same thing, but the packaging on both the toothbrush and the Ortho replacement head specifically say they are not compatible. I called OralB and their automated information confirmed the info on the packaging, these two are not compatible. Ugh...now I've got to go to the hassle of doing a return...
  420. I like the 2 minute timer. It keeps me accountable. I didnt think that i would b e using that feature, but it is really becoming part of my morning routine (and brushing will take another 2 minutes, so I have x amount of minutes left to get out the door).
  421. Another great product purchased from Amazon.
  422. Unit seems well built, feels solid and of good quality materials. My kids will use it and I need for them to be able to store two brush heads. The picture on Amazon's web site shows the unit with a storage base, but I only got the round charging base.

  427. I love this toothbrush! I've been using Oral B Electric Toothbrushes for as long as they were available until my pervious dentist suggested a Phillips Sonicare Electric Toothbrush. I was sorry I listened to his advice & switched to Phillips Sonicare. That was a big mistake, I've been having problems ever since before switching back to Oral B. I have a severe gag reflex & prefer the small brush heads. I was a heavy soda drinker and I love sweets. One day I went to the dentist complaining that my teeth hurt. It turned out I had a lot of Cavities. My pervious Dentist suggested the Phillips Sonicare toothbrush, so I bought that electric toothbrush. I hated it. It wasn't the right toothbrush for me. The brush head was so big, I was gaging when I tired to brush in the back. I felt like I was going to be sick when I used the Sonicare toothbrush and I would stop using it after 1 minute of using it every day & night. That led to a bad case of gingivitis, which he wanted to fix. He always tired to get me to come in for a cleaning every 3 months instead of every 6 months. I didn't want to do that because I couldn't afford it & I always believed 2 times a year was enough. I didn't want him to fix the gingivitis, I just wanted to walkout of his office. After that dentist appointment I wanted to go back to Oral B. I throw away the Phillips Sonicare toothbrush & I bought this electric toothbrush. I also switched to Crest Pro Health Toothpaste. I love that it has a small brush head. I can get to the back teeth easily without gaging myself. It's not a harsh head either. It feels very comfortable. Before when I was using the Phillips Sonicare Toothbrush, I could only stand to brush my teeth for 1 minute day & night before my gag reflex started acting up. With the Oral B toothbrush I can brush my teeth for the suggested 3-5 minutes amount without any gaging. I recently moved to a different state & I have a new dentist now. Before moving, I didn't go to the dentist for a year & a half. When I sat in the chair & opened my mouth, the hygienist immediately said that I did a great job brushing my teeth & she couldn't believe that I could get to the back teeth so easily. That was a great complement to me. I felt so proud of myself. Even the dentist told me that I did a great job brushing my teeth & he told me to keep up the good work! I will never go back to Phillips Sonicare. It might be a great toothbrush for a lot of people, but not for me. Thanks Oral B. I didn't think I would have a great checkup ever! Oral B & Crest Pro Health is a great combination! My mouth feels very clean & fresh! Just cutting the soda & sweets down helped a lot to! But, I owe everything to the Oral B Toothbrush! What a great product!a half.   430. The stress of a tough year is starting to get to me. I've been puckered up so tight for so long, I'm afraid my puckerer may have frozen that way.<br /><br />So I've been searching for inner peace -- and outer unpuckering -- in personal relaxation products. But expensive gadgets and doodads would just angry my blood up further, so I'm seeking Samadhi on a shoestring budget.<br /><br />Those vibrating chairs and pillows and personal massage doohickeys look pretty inviting -- but they're always so expensive. I figured it's the wiggling that does all of the work, so why not use a vibrating toothbrush to gently caress out my cares? Oral-B, take me away!<br /><br />The only downside is that the head on this brush is rather small, so it takes quite a bit of rubbing on my neck, temples or back to have any real impact. And by the time I've worked out a big knot between my shoulder blades, say, I've created an even bigger one from holding the toothbrush in one place for so long.<br /><br />If this came with some sort of clamp, or maybe a person to hold the brush for you, then it would be a nice massage tool for people. In the meantime, it's the perfect size to provide tension relief to my pet hamster. Mr. Nippers really seems to like our massage sessions. And his wheel running has been much looser and easy-going since we started. Nice product!
  431. I'll have to admit this is my first Oral-b ever since I started using an electric toothbrush and I am completely loving it! I decided on an Oral-b when my Sonicare started to give me trouble after 9 faithful years of use. Don't get me wrong this doesn't mean that Oral-b is better than Sonicare, it just means I prefer the Oral-b more. After using the Oral-b for a week I can honestly say it beats the Sonicare (the Elite/Essence model) in 2 key areas, its precision and the maintenance. The Oral-b's head is specifically designed to be round and small allowing users to clean each individual tooth while the structural design allow for simple and easy clean up. All you have to do to clean the unit is pull the head attachment off, rinse with water, and wipe clean with a towel or napkin. My old Sonicare, Elite model not flexcare, replacement heads was twisted on similar to a cup. This was extremely painful to clean because I would have to twist the head off, pop out the brush head, clean the round base, and then clean the handle mouth. If I didn't do this after each use the tooth paste drip off while brushing will seep inside the brush unit and the handle unit turning into mold. Completely unsanitary! Even after purchasing the SonicSeal, which I highly suggest to anyone who has the Elite/Essence model, mold would still build up at the bottom of the SonicSeal/Sonicare handle without proper cleaning. I also didn't feel like I had much precision cleaning my teeth because the brush head is long and wide. I always had to awkwardly position the brush to clean the inside of my teeth, the outer portion is really easy though.<br /><br />Beside these 2 factors, I think both toothbrush does a great job at cleaning your teeth, one just requires more work. I never really bought into the whole Oral-b vs. Sonicare debate because technically any electric toothbrush is better than a manual one. I get the same squeaky clean fresh feeling after I brush using either the Oral-b or Sonicare. Like I mentioned earlier, neither toothbrush is better than the other at cleaning your teeth, it's just the Oral-b gives you better precision and is easier to maintain.<br /><br />Some miscellaneous difference between the Oral-b and Sonicare (Elite model):<br /><br />1. The Oral-b works by oscillating (moving side by side), so there is no need to brush when its on just move it tooth to tooth. The Sonicare uses sonic technology by vibrating, so brushing is required when the unit is on or it won't clean at all just vibrates based on my experiences.<br /><br />2. The Oral-b has a quadrant timer just like the Sonicare. They will both pause after each 30 seconds indicating when to change quadrant, but unlike the Sonicare which stops automatically after 2 mins the Oral-b will continue on until prompted by the user to stop. I love this because I brush for 3 mins not 2.<br /><br />3. The charge indicator is different for both units. The Sonicare will blink green when charging and stay green when fully charged until removed from the charging base. The Oral-b will blink green when charging and stop blinking when fully charged. I had to pull out the manual to make sure the Oral-b was fully charged and working. I thought it malfunctioned because the light stayed off.I mentioned earlier, neither toothbrush is better than the other at cleaning your teeth, it's just the Oral-b gives you better precision and is easier to maintain.<br /><br />Some miscellaneous difference between the Oral-b and Sonicare (Elite model):<br /><br />1. The Oral-b works by oscillating (moving side by side), so there is no need to brush when its on just move it tooth to tooth. The Sonicare uses sonic technology by vibrating, so brushing is required when the unit is on or it won't clean at all just vibrates based on my experiences.<br /><br />2. The Oral-b has a quadrant timer just like the Sonicare. They will both pause after each 30 seconds indicating when to change quadrant, but unlike the Sonicare which stops automatically after 2 mins the Oral-b will continue on until prompted by the user to stop. I love this because I brush for 3 mins not 2.<br /><br />3. The charge indicator is different for both units. The Sonicare will blink green when charging and stay green when fully charged until removed from the charging base. The Oral-b will blink green when charging and stop blinking when fully charged. I had to pull out the manual to make sure the Oral-b was fully charged and working. I thought it malfunctioned because the light stayed off.

  480. Our 1000 model lasted us just over 10 months before the battery cell went bad.<br /><br />I call Oral-B. They assure me that the NiMh cells they use will last a minimum of three years and realistically a max of 5 years. Sounds great. If that happens, then I'll have gotten my money's worth from it.<br /><br />No problem. I've used these toothbrushes for 12 years now. They're workhorses. We just got a bad one.<br /><br />Send it in to a service center for warranty claim. Postage + insurance costs $8.<br /><br />Three weeks later, we get back a used charger and what appears to be a new 3000-series brush unit. Fine with us. Only two problems...It takes right at two days undisturbed on the charger to reach a full charge AND from full charge we get 2-3 brushings before the motor runs too slow to be useful.<br /><br />Another bad battery cell? I don't know. Maybe it's the used charger, but I doubt it.<br /><br />Another $8 to send this piece of crap back to the service center. Another three weeks to get it back.<br /><br />Good. A different used charger and a brush handle that also appears to be other than new. The female charge socket of the brush handle was quite scuffed and dirty, suggesting it had been on an off of a charging unit quite a bit, like maybe at someone else's house. I look at it and think, \\"Oh, good...I just paid $16 in postage for a used toothbrush.\\"<br /><br />We put this one on the charger. 2-1/2 days later (I'm not exaggerating) the handle shows a full charge. It's two weeks later now and it still takes 2-1/2 days on the charger to get a full charge. Obviously a bad cell, charger, or charging circuit, or a little of all three.<br /><br />Do I spend another $8 to repeat this process yet again (for the third time in six weeks)? Nope. $24 and 9 weeks of hassle just isn't a fair price for a used toothbrush.<br /><br />I was a long-time happy customer of this line of brushes. At present, I'm on the lower edge of just a customer of this line of brushes. And I'll jump ship as soon as I find something that I think might actually last.<br /><br />In my opinion, based on my experience, you should be pleasantly surprised if any of these electric brushes (of at least the 1000 and 3000 models) lasts more than a year. Going in with your expectations set low will most likely save you some of the frustration we've had with our several these past couple months.<br /><br />The brush still does a great job cleaning our teeth, but I've stopped looking at Oral-B as a tank and more as a disposable unit that will have to be replaced within a year.In my opinion, based on my experience, you should be pleasantly surprised if any of these electric brushes (of at least the 1000 and 3000 models) lasts more than a year. Going in with your expectations set low will most likely save you some of the frustration we've had with our several these past couple months. The brush still does a great job cleaning our teeth, but I've stopped looking at Oral-B as a tank and more as a disposable unit that will have to be replaced within a year.
