  516. Replaced another Oral B that was still working after 5 or so years. The new one makes a huge difference
  517. Works as you would expect, initial battery lasted only a year. Proceed if replacing battery is your last resort. If the product is out of warranty, the battery is replaceable. If you're savvy enough, use the battery disposal instructions and take everything apart gently (primarily \\"breaking\\" the cap off the bottom and don't use a screwdriver to pry the circuit board away from the battery). Original battery for me was a 1.2V 1100mAh Ni-MH AA battery w/ solder tabs (plenty of room for a capacity upgrade). There are 4 solder joints. Have fun.
  518. I like this brand oral-B. the price is good.
  519. a very powerful electrical toothbrush.<br />pro:<br />- Cheap, portable, powerful and easy to handle<br />con:<br />- little bit loud, no setting to adjust the rotation speed.
  520. I bought this to replace my many years old one of the same model. And so far this one is exactly as I expected. I control the length of time I brush each area of my teeth, and I like that I can easily change the type of various brush heads depending upon what function I want to perform.<br />More Whitening, more cleaning, sensitivity, etc. This is far superior to the lower end electronic toothbrushes and the easy to use plug in charging station keeps this running 7 days or longer on one charge, and there are NO batteries to mess with. If you need heavier duty cleaning, this isn't for you. This is the 20,000 pulses model. And the price on Amazon was the best I found.
  521. Good toothbrush. Twice a day for 2 minutes or more. Highly reviewed and for a reason, replace you normal tooth brush now and make the switch, you wont regret it.
  522. My new favorite tooth brush! Exceeded my expectations
  523. I bought this toothbrush after doing a little bit of research into Oral-B and Sonicare. The different I found between the two was that this not only vibrated, but the bristles rotate. The Sonicare brush only vibrates.<br /><br />It works great, my mouth definitely feels cleaner than with a manual toothbrush. What is nice is that the brush automatically vibrates extra every thirty (30) seconds, to let you know you should move to a knew place in your mouth. The instructions break up your mouth into four (4) quadrants with thirty (30) seconds a piece so you know you are spending adequate time in each area.<br /><br />I've owned it for a few weeks now and I have not had to charge it yet, and this is using it twice a day.<br /><br />I would highly recommend this brush to anyone thinking of buying an electric toothbrush.
  524. I didn't need lots of whistles and bells, just a tooth brush to clean my teeth. This does the job...well, simply and fast.
  525. The &#34;pulsating&#34; mentioned oh-so-briefly in the product description is actually a very unpleasant and extremely strong jackhammer effect.<br /><br />Had to return -- I could not use for more than a few seconds without developing a headache and nausea, much like motion sickness. I could feel the pounding of the brush throughout my skull.<br /><br />Not cool. I notice that a lot of the negative comments mention it, so apparently it's either more pronounced in some units than others, or many folks just aren't as bothered by it. Hard for me to believe, though -- it is RELENTLESS.
  526. I was looking for something better since my 12yr old oral b spinbrush was getting seasoned. Night & day feeling in my mouth. My teeth are far from perfect & bleed easy while brushing. Didn't have that problem & made me wanna brush more! It vibrates like crazy, takes some getting used to, no beeping every 30 seconds just on/off. Overall recommended for the cost.

  537. i purchased this product to replace an oral-b vitality sonic toothbrush. the rotational/vibrational action from this model i thought would provide superior cleaning. it absolutely does. as far as cleaning, it's a 5 star product. while it is possible to spend much more on an electronic toothbrush, i really doubt you are getting cleaner teeth for it.<br /><br />i have been using this product for 2 months now. i have to say it is kind of an ordeal to use this thing. it is loud. while brushing, it sounds like a cessna in flight. if you open your mouth just right, it will sound like someone is playing a didgeridoo in your bathroom. you should also know that, because it rotates, it can fling small toothpaste globs, so i don't recommend brushing with this just before you head out for work in the suit and tie. nothing stains quite like toothpaste. the brush head also seems like it is deeper to accommodate the moving parts. it's not as comfortable as other brushes i have used. it reaches everywhere, though. lastly, the timer goes off every 15-30 seconds to prompt you to change quadrants in your mouth. useful, but also kinda nagging.<br /><br />brushing your teeth used to be so simple. now it's an ordeal. but for the effectiveness of the cleaning, i guess it's worth it.

The power is markedly better and the every 30 second reminder to move to the next quadrant of my teeth is nice to make sure that I am spending appropriate time on each area. The starter toothbrush has a 2 minute timer which kind of leaves you guessing as to how much time on each area. The cleaning action of this brush is much better.Had I known the difference between the starter level and this one, I would have spent the extra 10 or 15 bucks for this one.   702. German made, what a difference. Everything worked even the brushhead is better quality compared to my travel Oral B Pro Health (battery operated, which is a real pain to open and change out batteries) which is made in China.<br /><br />Spinning at much higher RPM than my traveling one, I cant wait to have dental checkup to see if this thing (which cost just a tad more than Pro Health) really cleans better (I have considered the Rotadent for sometime but eventually rejected it because of the poor battery technology and high price in brushhead replacements).<br /><br />I actually do like the 30 seconds stutter reminder to brush different quadrant whereas before I have to watch my clock to do so.<br /><br />The only wish I have is the charger (which is really compact) can be used internationally (which at 110 it is not) so I can travel with it. So I am stuck with continuing using the Pro Health (which is about same size as the 1000) for travel.<br /><br />UPDATE: 10-10-2014<br /><br />Like this product so much bought another identical one. I started using the first one on a consistent basis for the last few months--ie-- brushing for exactly 2 minutes (30 seconds per quadrant) using the stutter reminder and guess what, my dental checkup came back flying colors, almost no plague. That has never happened to me before because I have not been brushing properly time wise or using the wrong kind of toothbrush. I really felt the round rotating brush head is a joy to use.<br /><br />Also per instruction to once and awhile run charges all the way to zero. From full charge I usually get about 5 days (twice daily) brushing, then red light will flash. Then I just keep using for few more days to totally run battery down before charging full.
  703. It does an excellent job of cleaning my teeth for the price. I have always used this brand and have never found its performance substandard.
  704. This is the first real electric tooth brush I've had (tried the cheap Crest Spin brush, but nothing on this level) and I did a lot of research ahead of time and decided the reviews and the price was the most reasonable with this brush. I absolutely love it. My mouth and teeth feel very clean once I'm done and my teeth are already looking whiter. The brush is small enough that I can reach all the way to the back teeth. The bristles are hard enough to feel like you got a good clean but soft enough that it doesn't hurt your gums. I like the vibrating timer for the 4 quadrants as well - it's gentle but noticible. My husband was skepticle and thought it would be like the Crest Spin brush but he tried mine and also really noticed the difference - so we got him one too and he really loves it as well. I think this is a great product and easy to transition to from regular brushes - the base is also small so doesn't take up much space in the bathroom.
  705. For many years I've used the Oral B budget version (appx. $20) of their pro electric toothbrush and loved it. The strong motor and small head just works so much better than most other brand of electric toothbrushes and infinitely more cleaner than using a manual brush. Since the design elements on the budget versions are similar to the pro versions and uses the same toothbrush head, I thought the budget Oral B electric toothbrush was just as good as the more expensive Oral-B Pros.<br /><br />However, when I got an Oral-B 1000 Pro Care Electric Toothbrush, the differences were very noticeable! I felt like I went from a classy compact car to a luxurious full-size premier sedan! The motor on the Oral-B 1000 is much more refined. The body is taller and more slender. It makes for a much better brushing experience.<br /><br />One of my unexpected pleasures of the Oral-B 1000 Pro toothbrush is the built in timers. One goes off once every 20 seconds to remind you to move onto the next section of your teeth. Then the 2-minute warning saying you've completed the recommended minimum time to brush your teeth. Nice! One kept me from working too fast, the other reminded me that it's time to finish up.<br /><br />I really like the small round toothbrush head. It reaches to the back teeth, gets into tight corners, and is able to give a good scrub in every dental nook and cranny. The blue bands fade over time to remind you to replace the toothbrush head after a while. (Con: I'm not fond on how expensive the toothbrush head replacements are - yikes!) Surely, the round brush head give me the best clean. No other toothbrush shape comes close.<br /><br />Overall, I'm loving the Oral-B 1000. It's an excellent toothbrush and a pleasure to use. It makes for a better tooth-brushing experience for me. I'll never go back if I can help it.
  706. Electric brushes can be a good thing - there is quite a bit more cleaning action going on because the automatic brush strokes are way faster than your hand can perform so you will always get better cleaning. Also, I have found the rotating action of the head allows you to position it in hard-to-reach areas and then just allow it to do its work, whereas it's much less likely to get sufficient cleaning action manually - especially if, like me, you still have some wisdom teeth left and you are concerned about keeping them from decaying.<br /><br />I also am an 'over-brusher', so I tend to brush too long and too vigorously, and have caused some unneccessary gum receding and enamel damage. That's one caution I would make with the electric toothbrushes - you get plenty of brushing action and 'more' is not necessarily better. Sometimes a light brushing and some flossing or toothpick action would serve you better than long, intense brushing. This brush has a light pause built into it to let you know you are brushing too hard - probably a good thing for those of us so interest in dental hygiene that we will buy these gizmos.<br /><br />One reason I got interested in the electronic toothbrushes, is I tend to brush up and down too hard and I was causing both irritation and receding in a couple areas of my gums and a friend mentioned that her dentist said the rotary-action of these brushes can help correct that a bit - sure enough, I found I stopped making my gum sore every time I brushed, plus brushing was so much more enjoyable in general.<br /><br />I started a few years back with the cell-type battery powered brushes, but they always tended to die on me in a few months, so about a year and a half ago, I went to Oral-B's cheapest re-chargeable model. I had absolutely no problems with it. When I went to the dentist recently after not having gone for over twenty years, they seemed to think my teeth were in outstanding shape, except for the fact that I was over-brushing.<br /><br />The difference in the smooth-running feel of this nicer tooth-brush versus the cheaper Oral-B one is pretty noticeable - the same level of difference I noticed when going from the cell-type battery brushes to my first Oral-B rechargeable one. Both rechargeable models have the built-in 'three big pauses' signal to let you know you have brushed for a full two minutes, however, I am re-thinking whether I need to follow the 2-minute recommendation every time I brush, since over-brushing is the greatest bane my teeth have.<br /><br />A couple recommendations: This brush will accomodate the 'dual-action' heads, and once I tried those, going back to the single action was really lame. Dual-action rocks.<br /><br />Also, in case you don't know, always take the head off of the brush, rinse well, and leave it off to dry, just putting back on the next time you brush. This should keep any bacteria from growing in the brush head. If you still notice a smell of bacteria, or just want to make sure to get it extra clean, use very hot water when rinsing or even have a spray bottle of strong alcohol available to spray into the bottom of the brush head before you lay it down to dry out. I noticed a change in brushing heads was called for in anywhere from three to six months, not because the bristles wear down, but the head becomes slightly looser and it would sort of start pinching my gum or tongue a bit as my skin could get slightly caught between the loose plastic. The miser in me wants to continue until the head simply falls apart, but it's much better to just break down and get a new one at that point, thereby avoiding the discomfort, and getting back to enjoying the luxury of a nice electronic toothbrush.<br /><br />Also, I followed the instructions in the package of my last rechargeable to allow the battery to completely drain every three months or so. This is a bit of a challenge, because the brush turns off by itself, so even though you leave it off the charger, once it's worn down a bit, it will stop and turn off, even though it is not completely drained. I found that simply hitting the 'on' button as many times as I could as I went by, I was able to get it down to truly dead, but it generally requires using the bush manually for a day or so, until it is completely dead and then you can charge it back up. I did this because I wanted my brush to last as long as possible and will do it with this new one too. I'm assuming it does something like clear the memory on the battery when you allow it to go completely dead.<br /><br />Two of my personal dental hygiene recommendations: Be a bit careful about using baking soda or toothpastes with strong abrasives if you are an 'over-brusher' which can cause even more worn enamel. Also, 'tartar control' products are highly under-rated in my opinion. I personally feel the chemicals in pastes and rinses that say 'tartar-control' really work, although I will admit, my dentist doesn't seem one bit impressed with them. Still, I used these products faithfully for the 20 years I had no professional dental care, and I had hardly any tartar build-up when I got my teeth cleaned, whereas previously, I did not use the products, and went to the dentist every 6 months and they seemed to find a reasonable amount of tartar to scrape off each time.<br /><br />Anyway, this is a wonderful product that makes an annoying daily-plus chore downright enjoyable and keeps your teeth looking and chewing nicely. Just don't over-brush.f, even though it is not completely drained. I found that simply hitting the 'on' button as many times as I could as I went by, I was able to get it down to truly dead, but it generally requires using the bush manually for a day or so, until it is completely dead and then you can charge it back up. I did this because I wanted my brush to last as long as possible and will do it with this new one too. I'm assuming it does something like clear the memory on the battery when you allow it to go completely dead. Two of my personal dental hygiene recommendations: Be a bit careful about using baking soda or toothpastes with strong abrasives if you are an 'over-brusher' which can cause even more worn enamel. Also, 'tartar control' products are highly under-rated in my opinion. I personally feel the chemicals in pastes and rinses that say 'tartar-control' really work, although I will admit, my dentist doesn't seem one bit impressed with them. Still, I used these products faithfully for the 20 years I had no professional dental care, and I had hardly any tartar build-up when I got my teeth cleaned, whereas previously, I did not use the products, and went to the dentist every 6 months and they seemed to find a reasonable amount of tartar to scrape off each time. Anyway, this is a wonderful product that makes an annoying daily-plus chore downright enjoyable and keeps your teeth looking and chewing nicely. Just don't over-brush.
  707. It was a surprise to find that a smaller round brush head could work so much better than a standard larger round head or oval head electric toothbrush. This smaller brush head also had a strong massaging action which felt great on my gums. With the smaller size head, I could get to all the hard to reach dental surfaces such as the back of the very posterior molars plus the inside of the incisors and canines.<br /><br />The handle itself is slightly grooved so that it is less likely to slip when damp. It's much thinner than other electric toothbrushes, so it is less tiring to hold. The design is slender and sleek with a narrow charging base that takes up less space on a bathroom counter top. The unit also has a timer so you can insure you are actually brushing long enough.<br /><br />After brushing for three minutes or more twice a day for a week, my teeth felt extra clean similar to the feeling I get after I've received a professional teeth cleaning. I was surprised that a smaller brush head could be so much more efficient, but indeed it was compared with my SoniCare electric toothbrush which costs twice as much. In my opinion, purchasing this Oral-B 1000 electric toothbrush is a good investment not only to get cleaner teeth but also to benefit from an efficient gum massage!

  732. So the Precision 1000 works really well. The battery lasts a long time, and it does a pretty decent job at getting in between teeth (of course it's no replacement for flossing). I can't really compare this to other electric tooth brushes as I've never owned any, but this seems to do the job nicely.<br /><br />The timing feature on the brush lets you know when 30 seconds has passed so you can move on to another quarter of your mouth, and then finally when two minutes are up and you're all done. This works pretty well, but not brushing long enough was never a problem for me. I kind of wish I could deactivate this feature (especially since you can't pause it to spit).<br /><br />While the brush handle itself is nice and quiet, the brushing heads that come with the brush are a little loud. Not &#34;I need ear plugs&#34; loud, but definitely &#34;hey guys, guess who's brushing their teeth in the bathroom!&#34; loud. If your spouse is a light sleeper, maybe this would be a problem? Not sure.<br /><br />Also, for some reason Amazon has the brush pictured with a large base. It doesn't come with one. It's just a compact little stand. It charges the brush wirelessly, which is cool, and I honestly prefer the smaller base. Don't know why they picture it having a base like that. I believe that's the base that actually comes with the Precision 3000 instead.<br /><br />Over all, great tooth brush. The charge lasts long enough that you can travel with this brush easily. I recommend it.

Otherwise you're likely to find it uncomfortable and have bleeding gums.   827. This is for the Oral-B Professional Healthy Clean Precision 1000.<br /><br />This does a great job at getting my teeth clean. I've used some other kinds and brands of electric toothbrushes (all more expensive than this one) and I think I like this one the most. I appreciate that it is relatively cheap compared to most of the other options and I think it does at least a good of a job at cleaning my teeth. I like the feature of it letting you know every 30 seconds to change spots.<br /><br />One thing I don't like is the way the heads are designed. The part that enters your mouth is not sealed and there is an opening further down the head which is still outside your mouth. I never realized it before but parts of my brushing routine is done with my mouth closed tight around the tooth brush. This just isn't possible with this head so I have to continually inhale gently to keep spit from coming out through the toothbrush head. I've gotten used to it but the truth is I still sometimes end up with toothpaste spit down the front of me, a problem I've never had with any other toothbrush.<br /><br />The only other complaint is the battery. The first one I had went dead within about a month. I sent it in for repair and they replaced the battery. It's been about 5 months since then and it seems to be fine now. Still, all of these rechargeable batteries have the same problem: they never last as long as they are supposed to. To prolong the life of the battery I would strongly recommend not putting it on the charger after every use. Wait until the low battery light flashes. I get about 15 brushes per charge. That's a pretty reasonable number but unless I'm very lucky, it won't take long before the charge starts dropping off fast.

  841. Bought this due to some minor dental issues. About 15 years ago I bought the same Braun/Oral B system just like this to assist in correcting the same problem. I loved it then and this one is working just the same but with some improvements. I like how the mortorized handle has a very nice waterproof coating. Also, it is helpful that the &#34;timer&#34; goes off every 30 seconds by changing the brush pattern for 2 seconds - so if you are trying to acheive a full 2 minutes with giving equal attention to areas of the mouth, this is helpful. Also, it does not just shut off instantly after 2 min, it seems to slow down a bit. From reading the manual, it indicates there are 2 speeds - the second one is &#34;gentle&#34; or &#34;sensitive&#34;, although I have not tried it.<br /> The only con for me is the bright light. My bathroom is very small without much counter space. Therefore, many of my bathroom items are just outside the door on a small/short bookcase next to an outlet. This is perfect for many things but when I plug this Braun toothbrush into the outlet, there is a large &#34;charge&#34; icon that lights up very bright blue. This honestly might work as a nightlight in a bathroom if you wanted it too - it is that bright. However, this is in my bedroom and it is too bright. I corrected it by putting a small piece of aluminum foil over the light and it blocks it completely and the foil is &#34;water-proof&#34;. Alternatively, the charge lasts for 14 two-minute brush sessions (or one week of twice per day use), so one could just plug it in when leaving in the morning and unplug at night, then wait another week to do the same.<br /> Overall, very happy with this item.
  842. If your looking at this product, your are already thinking about functionality. Even though this model is more towards the basic side of features compared to the other models, it's all you need for brushing teeth. Honestly I don't think anyone needs timers, a stand, self-cleaning feature, and a pressure sensor for brushing teeth. This brush will do the job just fine. It does have features like, 1 second pauses for every 30 seconds to let you know you need to move on to the next quadrant of your mouth for brushing. A small easy travel charging dock (if you are going to be gone for more than 5 days and have to possibly need to recharge), and easy to understand battery indicators. And above all the price. I bought 2 of these in the same transaction for $27 a piece, at walmart they were $65 a piece. After one month of brushing teeth and before using a traditional tooth brush, I noticed a significant improvement.
  843. My first electric tooth brush and all I can say is it does the job well. We'll see how well it goes over time.
  844. I've never had an electric toothbrush before, but my dentist recommended I get one after my latest cleaning, reminding me that I needed to brush for 2 full minutes, because otherwise it simply isn't effective, and that the electric softer can do a better job anyways while reminding us how long we've brushed. This basic product is awesome. You can FEEL when the brush has hit a 30 second mark (it does a 1/4 second &#34;stop&#34; twice) and the continues brushing, so you can move to a new quadrant of your mouth. Once it hits 2 minutes, it does a longer stop sequence, then continues brushing if you want to brush more (your tongue perhaps?). Overall, this is much better than regular toothbrushes, with a really unobtrusive charger, so I won't ever be going back to regular brushes.

  854. Coffee + teas w/ fruits (especially the blueberry) had resulted in significant staining of these older teeth, requiring significant efforts by the hygienist to clean them up. At the urging of the professionals, acquired the Oral-B and have reduced the staining by at least 90%. The only down side is the induction recharging, which requires a good 15 to 17 hours for full recharge. So, if the low battery shows at night and set to recharge, the unit will not be fully recharged until the following evening. A charge lasts about a week, used twice a day, consistent w/ the informational pamphlet. But if more than one person uses it, that really cuts down the use time, and that's where the overly long recharge period is an issue. \\"Constant\\" recharge would likely solve the issue, but at the cost of reducing the life of the battery itself. Yes, the induction system has no exposed contacts, looks \\"neat\\", etc., but sacrifices efficient recharge time (maybe that's why these are also available as 2-unit packs). Overall, the Oral-B has done wonders for the teeth, but the excessive recharge time gets the product 4 stars, not 5.
  855. Having used other electronic toothbrushes, I found this one brushes harder than others and isn't as soft bear the gum line. Also, the neck of the brush is bigger than others and I find toothpaste easily runs down the brush when brushing

  859. I bought this as a replacement for an older Oral-B power toothbrush because I was fed up with the effort required to clean the charging base. No more need to count myself to know when to switch to another area of the mouth. Another reviewer mentioned that it's only 110V so not suitable for travel to countries with 220V power.   861. I've never had an issue with brushing manually and therefore have held off buying an electric toothbrush. For a variety of reasons (temporary price drop to $50 on Amazon, $20 mail-in rebate, 5% credit card bonus points from purchases from Amazon with one of my credit cards from Jan1 thru Mar31, 2012), I thought I'd give this a try since my overall commitment would be under $30.<br /><br />I bought the Oral-B Professional Care 1000 after checking the various Amazon reviews from others of their various models. I also bought a 3-pack of the floss action brush heads for future use. So far, I've used the included standard brush head with my 1000 brush for about a week. My impressions:<br /><br />-as I read the product info and some folks' reviews, I thought the 30-sec stutter timer was a bit of a gimmick. But having used the brush for about a week now, I like knowing when my quarter-mouth 30-sec period is complete so I can brush for the recommended 2 minutes.<br /><br />-I had no issues with initial gum bleeding and am happy with the results of brushing with the 1000 compared to my earlier manual brushing. I generally buy extra soft bristles for my manual toothbrushes so I expected I'd need to buy the Sensitive brush heads for the 1000, but I'm happy with the standard brush head that came with the 1000.<br /><br />-initially, I didn't think the 1000 was doing a better job than my manual brushing that I've been doing now for over 60 years, BUT... I do think that my morning flossing goes easier since switching to the 1000, so I will confess that maybe the 1000 does better than my old manual brush has done.<br /><br />-even with the cost of replacement heads, I expect to keep using and preferring the 1000 over manual brushing into the future. I will say though, that if my 1000 dies, I'll wait for a good sale on a replacement rather than run right out and buy a replacement the day the 1000 died. I still could easily live with manual brushing.<br /><br />-the one issue I have with my 1000 is that I tried to test the pressure sensor alert to see what the result would be and what level of pressure the brush considers to be too much. Maybe my unit is defective or maybe I don't know what to expect, but I don't think I've experienced an alert from my 1000 when pressing too hard.<br /><br />Just one more cute observation--when looking to buy this toothbrush, I did also check a well-known internet auction site--yes, that one--and was very surprised to observe that in addition to Sellers offering new units, some sellers were offering \\"slightly used\\" electric Oral-B Pro Care model 1000 toothbrushes. Ick! Who in their right mind would....oh, never mind.ert to see what the result would be and what level of pressure the brush considers to be too much. Maybe my unit is defective or maybe I don't know what to expect, but I don't think I've experienced an alert from my 1000 when pressing too hard.   875. I got this for $25 after rebate from walmart.com yesterday, I already love it. I timed myself with a regular toothbrush & realized I've always only brushed for less than a minute. This electric toothbrush pulsates after every 30 seconds so I know when to move on to the next quadrant of my mouth. I never knew why I couldn't get all the white off my tongue with a regular toothbrush, this Oral-B removed all the white the first time!<br />You can get generic replacement heads for about $1 each by searching ebay for \\"oral-b precision heads\\" (about $3.33 each for oral-b brand replacement heads).

  880. A gift for a person who didn't like to brush his teeth and, like me, now finds it enjoyable, including a light massage of the gums. It tells you when the battery is low and buzzes every 30 seconds for 2 minutes to ensure you get all sections of your mouth and brush your teeth for the recommended 2 minutes.   885. I'd used battery operated toothbrush for years, but it seemed like I had to replace them about every 3rd or 4th time the batteries needed replacing. Then moved on to an Oral B Vitality and what a difference. I had that for years. It let you know when you'd been brushing for 2 minutes and the charge lasted long enough to get me through a 3-day power outage. Not sure how much longer it would have lasted beyond that. But alas, it eventually started to feel like it was losing power. So wow, what a difference when I got this one. Did the Vitality ever feel this strong? I'm not sure now.<br /><br />It took quite a while to charge it up for the first time, so make sure you have something else available, just to play it safe on that first day. A light blinks to let you know when it's charging.<br /><br />Didn't think I'd like the brush head that came with it. I actually liked an older brush head that just recently you can't seem to get anymore that had two brushes on it. But I was surprised as the design of this head feels like it cups each tooth while doing its job and your teeth actually feel cleaner, almost as smooth as just coming from the dentist.<br /><br />You're notified via a momentary stuttering of the pulse every 30 seconds. This is designed so that you work on one quadrant of your mouth at a time and eventually trains you to the tempo of how much time to spend on each tooth. You'll also receive additional momentary stutters if you're pressing to hard on your teeth.<br /><br />It's supposed to last a total of 14 2-minute brushings before the charge is depleted. They do suggest completely running the charge down every 6 months to make it last longer.

  901. Love the product, not happy with the rebate. Did not get it, I need a receit.<br />Didn't get one online. Help
  902. I own both the Philips Sonicare Essence 5300 and the Oral-B Professional Care 1000 and have used both extensively. They are very different toothbrushes.<br /><br />The Philips uses sonic technology that causes the brush to vibrate extremely fast without it actually moving much; this subtle quality creates a more pleasant brushing experience than the Oral-B. It also has a longer more traditional brush that I like better for tongue cleaning, and for getting into certain spaces between teeth. I find the brush ends too sharp and uncomfortable to use for gum massaging.<br /><br />The Oral-B has a round brush that acts more like a jackhammer in that it is much more physical and vigorous than the Philips. I can also apply more pressure with the Oral-B (important for cleaning molars). These two qualities makes it better for deep cleaning. The brush is also softer than the Philips, which combined with the \\"vigorous\\" quality makes it better for gum massaging.<br /><br />Which one I use depends on what I want. I use the Oral-B about 65% of the time, the Philips about 35%. I give the edge to Oral-B since deep cleaning is most important to me, though I'm still glad I have the Philips for light jobs.
  903. Awesome, easy to use. Exactly as I was hoping. Powerful when charged and charges quickly.
  904. The small head is perfect to reach into all of the nooks and crannies of the mouth. No more wasting money on batteries as it's rechargeable, and the battery lasts about one week before it needs to be charged.
  905. I own both a Sonicare and an Oral-B and I like the Oral-B much better because of the round brush. For me, it felt awkward cleaning the lingual surface of the mandibular anterior teeth with the shape of the brush on the Sonicare. With the Oral-B, no matter which teeth you're cleaning or whatever angle, the round brush is all over it and cleans perfectly. This difference is huge and on close inspection, I noticed the Oral-B left my teeth cleaner.
  906. My 10-year-old Oral-B toothbrush was failing - the battery wasn't fully charging and the RPMs and power were down - so I decided it was time for a new toothbrush. Since I still had a couple of Oral-B brush tips and because I liked the brand, I decided to stay with Oral-B.<br />My Precision 1000 arrived yesterday afternoon and I used it for the first time last night.<br />I was stunned at the speed and power. This thing is like a ferret on meth (in a good way, of course) and left my mouth feeling way fresher and cleaner than did my old brush.<br />My only complaint is that the price dropped $10 this week.<br />Great product.   907. Great tool. My dentist love s my new look....
  908. Only gripe is the blinking green light when charging, because the vanity area and outlet are inside my bedroom, so it lights up in the night.
  909. So far I've gotten this toothbrush for 3 different people as gifts. One was for my mother over a year ago, the second my sister (also over a year ago), and lastly my husband recently got one from me. So far this toothbrush has yet to fail them and they all love it! It works well, leaving them with a clean mouth. It is rechargeable, which is what I always recommend to my patients (I am a dental hygienist). Many people prefer the battery operated ones due to the cheaper price, but when you add up the cost of batteries you're really losing money in the long run. Furthermore, rechargeable keeps its energy up, meaning it spins better than it does with a dying battery. Also, for the cost this is almost just as good as the much more expensive rechargeable toothbrushes. Sure the bells and whistles aren't all there but you'll still get a clean smile that will make your hygienist proud of you. Just be sure to brush 2x/day for 2 full minutes, floss at least 1x/day (no matter how good of a toothbrush you have you still have to floss), brush your tongue via tongue scraper 2x/day, and use your antimicrobial mouthwash for a full 30 seconds 2x/day. Do this and your dentist will love you.<br /><br />Overall, I highly recommend this toothbrush.
  910. I love it! It really clean my teeth. After you brush, you can feel your teeth surface feel just right after ur dentist visit. I had oral-b sonic toothbrush 4 yrs ago and I thought that was good but this new one is 1/4 of cost of my old one and does the better job!

  915. This here toothbrush along with some whitening toothpaste, and I have entered a whole new world of clean teeth. Terrific product and SO worth the relatively small amount of money for it! Doesn't take up much counter space at all, and vibrates powerfully for a good clean. Time your brush for you so you get the recommended 2 minutes cut into 4ths (one for each quarter of the mouth). Will stop if you press down to hard. Only drawback is a 22-hour charge time from bottom to top, and a recommendation to fully discharge the battery at least every 6 months to preserve the rechargeable battery. But a full battery lasts for 7 days of 2x/day brushing. Glad I bought this!

  926. This is my second oral b toothbrush purchase, the first one I bought more than 12 YEARS ago! The switch started failing recently so I decided to purchase this model to replace it. At first I thought the price of an electric toothbrush was a bit much, but after using one I will never go back to a manual brush. The clean feeling the oral b delivers cant be matched by manually brushing IMO. This new model I believe is faster than the older model it replaced, if you have never used a brush like this you may need to go a little easy on pressure to get used to it. You may also experience your gums bleeding but eventually that will go away. It seems to take forever to charge this brush, but I just do it overnight and it lasts me a over a week before it needs recharged. I run the brush till the battery is almost dead before i recharge it, this model also has a recharging-charged led which I find handy. I dont hesitate to take this brush with me away from home either, camping-traveling no problem at all. I paid more for the older model than I did this one, IMO it's a steal at the price they currently have it listed for!
  927. This replaces a dead Cybersonic 2 that I had for 12 years. For a really long time now, it wouldn't hold a charge - just long enough for me to use it once, then I'd have to stick it back on the charger again. Then the switch was malfunctioning, so yeah, time for a new one. I picked this model because I wanted to try the Floss Action head, and it was a step up from Vitality which moves at about 1/4 of the speed of this one. The higher models move at twice the speed of this one and have a couple more settings, but then I thought, \\"do I really need that?\\" I thought it might've been overkill, and just didn't have a ton of money to spend on a toothbrush this time around. When I lucked out and saw a new one of these on eBay for $27.99/free ship (didn't wanna hassle with the rebate), I decided to give it a try. It comes with 1 Precision head, but there was a $3 coupon enclosed, and the Floss Action heads were on sale at Walgreen's. So I got a 3-pack of FA heads for $18.99. Not bad for instant gratification. I really like tongue cleaner attachments, so I also managed to order the Mouthcare Essentials kit for $18.99/free ship from Bonanza (I think this kit goes for $45).<br /><br />I've been using it for 3 days. On my first day, my first thought was that it was scary-percussive. I was afraid that it was gonna knock my teeth loose! But I kept using it, and thankfully my teeth are still intact. It is a little loud, but I think they all are. What I like about this type of loud is that it's a low-pitched hum - like a really quiet biplane (haha, if you can imagine that) - so it's not too annoying. There are stutters to let you know how long you've been brushing, but they're easy enough to ignore, and the unit doesn't turn itself off. Nice, since I brush for way longer than 2 minutes. It stutters too when you're brushing too hard, which is a welcome feature that I didn't have before. Having the unit with all my attachments just willy nilly on my counter, or even in a drawer, was driving me nuts, but I found a small bait-and-tackle type case at Daiso for $1.50 that fits everything perfectly (I'll try to post a pic). A pencil case would've done the trick too, but Target's assortment wasn't so good this year. My Cybersonic had head covers and a base for the unit and all the attachments. The higher models probably have one too, but I don't know how useful they are, and this one little quirk certainly wasn't worth the added expense to me - so I'm happy with the one I got.<br /><br />The -1 star is because of the head. The diameter of the bristles is fine - what really bugs me is the depth of the fat stem. I wish they could've made it a little flatter, or at least recessed that area where the part with the bristles attaches to it. That protrusion totally prevents me from getting the bristles to the chewing area of my back teeth, which really pisses me off, because I like to be thorough. So I end up having to hit those manually with my old Cybersonic head. Bummer. I've had to readjust how I brush my inner bottom fronts too. I have to hold the handle upside-down and almost completely vertical, and hit those from above. I don't remember ever having to do that with my Cybersonic. Awkward. But other than that, I'm pretty happy with my purchase. Especially since I got everything so cheap!iving me nuts, but I found a small bait-and-tackle type case at Daiso for $1.50 that fits everything perfectly (I'll try to post a pic). A pencil case would've done the trick too, but Target's assortment wasn't so good this year. My Cybersonic had head covers and a base for the unit and all the attachments. The higher models probably have one too, but I don't know how useful they are, and this one little quirk certainly wasn't worth the added expense to me - so I'm happy with the one I got.<br /><br />The -1 star is because of the head. The diameter of the bristles is fine - what really bugs me is the depth of the fat stem. I wish they could've made it a little flatter, or at least recessed that area where the part with the bristles attaches to it. That protrusion totally prevents me from getting the bristles to the chewing area of my back teeth, which really pisses me off, because I like to be thorough. So I end up having to hit those manually with my old Cybersonic head. Bummer. I've had to readjust how I brush my inner bottom fronts too.   935. I bought this to replace a Braun Oral B electric toothbrush I have owned for over ten years--it still works just fine, but I thought I should have another one ready to replace it when it failed, as I assumed it must, eventually. Both the old and the new products are made in Germany, which explains why the old one still works as well as it did when it was new. The new one (1000) has a smaller charging station, which I thought would be more convenient for travel. My only complaint about the new brush is that it signals (by a hesitation pulse) every 30 seconds, instead of just after two minutes--which is what the old brush does. I prefer the two-minute signal and find it mildly annoying to have to count the 30-second signals instead. Other than that, I am perfectly happy with it, and thrilled to find something that is still made in Germany.

The unit has been holding its charge for a week between being used 4 times a day.   955. I've had this for about a month. It's awesome. I was using an earlier model of an Oral-B electric toothbrush that was dying. But this 1000 is a hundred times better than the earlier model was when it was new. The motor is not too loud and they've improved the timing mechanism so that it tells you every 30 seconds when to start brushing another area. I am able to keep my teeth squeaky clean. I know my dentist will notice the difference.
  956. I am having no problems with this toothbrush. It is a bit noisy as written in other reviews. This does not bother me. The battery holds a charge very well, so far. I wait a week between charges. No loss of power in a week.
  957. I've used manual toothbrushes all my life and was never interested in electric toothbrushes, despite me taking good care of my teeth. Recently I got braces and my teeth started getting a yellow tan because it's not very easy to get in between the braces. Then I got this bad boy and I've got to say it's been the best thing I've done for my mouth! My teeth are very clean now and in a week my teeth have become whiter, and it's very easy to clean in between my braces!!!
  958. Terrific! This was recommended by my periodontist, and it really makes your teeth &#34;dentist clean&#34;. I change the brush head every three months as recommended. He said if it gets frayed, it does not clean properly.
  959. I've been using Oral-B toothbrushes for several years and love how they work. The round heads are more maneuverable than the conventionally-shaped heads on the Sonic Care and, for me, do a better job cleaning my teeth. Plus the Oral-B heads are less expensive in general, and tend to go on sale regularly to keep the long-term costs manageable.<br /><br />Although I use their top of the line 5000 series at home, I wanted something for travel use that was less bulky. This caught my eye mainly due to price -- after the manufacturer rebate the final cost was less than $25.<br /><br />I'm finding it to be just as capable as their far more expensive 5000 series. While it lacks several of the more advanced features (the timer display module and various speeds, such as sensitive, gum massage, etc.) it gets the job done. To be honest, most of the time on my 5000 I just use the regular speed, so there's no real loss of functionality with the 1000 model.<br /><br />It supposedly has fewer pulsations per minute than the more expensive models (20,000 per minute versus 40,000 per minute for the 3000 to 5000 series). I can't feel a measurable difference. My teeth feel just as clean after using this versus my 5000 model.<br /><br />The overall size of the handle and charger is more compact than the 5000 series making it much easier to pack in a travel case.<br /><br />No bells and whistles like the more expensive Oral B models, but a much better value. Highly recommend.
  960. Love the this product! This model has given me the proper cleaning tool and my dental tech is more than pleased. Thanks
  961. This is my 3rd OralB toothbrush and the company must be making cutbacks because it no longer comes with those little pegs that you use to put your toothbrush heads on. Now, that's not a big deal if you're single, but when two of you are using the same handle, then one of you isn't going to have any place to put your brush head...but not to fear, for a meer $7.00 (plus $5.15 shipping & handling) you can now BUY the holder! Woo hoo!
  962. Upgraded to this electric toothbrush from an older model Oral-B. This is a great toothbrush. Rather than just alerting you when it's time to stop brushing (after 2 minutes) it alerts you by pulsating once every 30 seconds - so that it's time to move &#34;quadrants.&#34; This takes some getting use to but it actually does help. The brush head is great that it comes with, and really feels like it does the job. The footprint of the actual charging station is tiny, so it doesn't take up too much room on my bathroom counter. It holds the charge for about a week, and alerts me when it's time to re-charge. The manual says you can leave the charger plugged in and it won't hurt the brush, but I just unplug it for whatever energy savings it gives me. Overall a great electric toothbrush for a great price. Only wish that it would have included a replacement head.
  963. Great toothbrush. I've used Oral-B electric toothbrushes for many years and this is the best one so far. I really like that the battery stays charged for so long. There are numerous features, but it's easy to use. The appearance is good, too. The packaging was very good and the instructions are clearly written with good illustrations. I recommend this product.
  964. The saying \\"you get what you pay for\\" applies. I've used Oral B electric toothbrushes for years. I liked the small footprint of the charger, plus a $20 rebate! How could I lose? This is truly a piece of junk. It rattles, it vibrates like a jack hammer, it even sounds cheap and like it's going to fall apart. Yes, I did get my rebate, unlike several people who reviewed this. The worst 2 things, tho, are that water somehow gets in the brush head and, unless you take it off and rinse out the inside, it starts smelling like swamp water. It's not just the head that came with the toothbrush. I've replaced the head, and the same thing happens. Pretty gross. I have to take the brush off every couple of days and soak it in Listerine antibiotic mouthwash. So apparently the unit doesn't seal to the brush somehow, despite the little o-rings that come with the brush heads. The second thing is that this wonderful small footprint charger get very hot. I'm very careful to dry the entire toothbrush every time I use it, but within a couple of days, a brown burnt gunk starts forming on the charger surface (the part that the toothbrush sits on) and every day there's more until I scrape it off and start over again. I think I'll just order another one and try to shame Oral B into a refund. This hot charger and burnt gunk make it hazardous, I think. Next time, I'll get the one I usually get. Pay the money and forget the cheap.
  965. The head stops spinning periodically for a couple seconds during use, feels underpowered. Bought two and both behave the same way.

There are no fancy settings, although this one will shut down if you press to hard against your teeth. That's a good thing because you really can wear off enamel from hard and frequent brushing.   1003. My Sonicare stopped charging so I did some research and settled on this toothbrush. The Sonicare head was pretty big and I had trouble reaching my back molars. I had to use a kid-sized manual brush to reach them and using two toothbrushes was getting tedious.<br /><br />I decided to give this a try since my dentist recommended them. Well, it cleans well, but it hurt my teeth. I bought a package of Sensitive Heads and that alleviated the issue. I think Oral B should package those with the brush instead of the regular ones. I want to clean my teeth, not strip them of enamel.<br /><br />This also provides a \\"stutter\\" to let you know when to move on to the next quadrant of your mouth. I find it unnecessary and a little annoying. If you're brushing properly the stutter is not needed.<br /><br />Oral B says that there is a \\"brushing too hard\\" indicator, but I can't seem to get it to trip. I've tried pressing very hard on my teeth and nothing happens. I just try to remember to grip the brush loosely. It's a toothbrush, not an icepick.<br /><br />I get almost two weeks out of a full charge. I unplug the charger when I'm not actively charging the brush. The directions say you can leave it plugged in, but that's what I did with my old Sonicare and the battery wouldn't hold a charge for more than 12 hours. The battery technology is different in the Oral B, but I'm not really one to take chances.<br /><br />I also like that this brush is made in Germany.<br /><br />Overall, I'm glad I bought this brush instead of another Sonicare.

  1033. I highly recommend the Oral-B Professional Care 1000 Electric Toothbrush. As usual, Amazon's service was exceptional. My teeth have never been good. This toothbrush really does a great job. My first Oral-B was purchased in 2001, a Plaque Remover 3-D. It still works & I still use it. The handle design has not changed much. The 1000 is quieter & vibration is almost non existent. The charging lights which indicate status of charging & low indicator are new & welcome. The charging light blinks while charging & goes out when fully charged. Beware, charging times are LONG. It can easily take 16 hours for a full charge when run down. You can choose to just return it to the plugged in charger after brushing, & thus not worry about charging. It will shut off when peak charge is reached. Without renewed charging, a full charge will last 35-40 minutes. The other improvement is the shorter, 30 second warnings which time your quarterly mouth brushing routine. I like this feature since it does improve your brushing technique with this feedback. The brush pauses are brief & don't affect actual brushing.<br /><br />The brush heads have been greatly improved over the years. New Precision Clean brush heads are a bit larger & really are tailored to the size of the individual tooth. These heads do a better job creating the \\"bubbles\\" from the toothpaste. I also noticed the massage affects are improved. I really can feel the difference! Four brush heads are available, with different designs & functions. Heads are a bit pricy, but do last a long time, at least for me. Don't apply pressure with this brush, it isn't necessary. Just touch the brush to your teeth & let the brush do the work.<br /><br />The 1000 cleanup is a snap. Just pull the brush head off & wipe the handle with a damp washcloth. The brush heed snaps on easily & remains firm while brushing. I had an earlier Waterpic that had a problem in this area. I personally prefer the smaller, circular brush head of the 1000 to the more traditional linear type of head used by Sonicare. It's design to fit each individual tooth enables more flexibility in the style of your brushing, more like a dental instrument. Try it.traditional linear type of head used by Sonicare. It's design to fit each individual tooth enables more flexibility in the style of your brushing, more like a dental instrument. Try it.

It also vibrates very quickly and you only need to plug the charger in when you are recharging - not all the time as I did with my previous one. It signals when its time to plug in the charger. The first time (and only time so far as I've only had it a few weeks) it signals that it was time to recharge I didn't realize it meant plug it in immediately so the next time I went to use it, it died while I was brushing. This one seems easy to keep clean and hygenic. We pop the brush heads off and keep them in a little container next to the brush where it sits on it's charger base. We pop the head off after every use and dry the end with a towel just to make sure we keep things clean.<br /><br />I like the timer feature.<br />There's a big difference in thinking you've done the proper amount of brushing time and ACTUALLY doing the right amount of brushing time.<br /><br />Like I said above, it's verrry powerful. It's not like the old school electrics that were weak and barely wiggled this is very aggressive.<br />If you have sore gums or something you might want to use caution and investigate whether this is the right brush for you.<br />After I had my buckles fixed my gums were sore from the work and the needles and I had to stop using this brush until they healed. My manual brush felt insignificant in comparison, was happy to get back to using this brush.

I have really bad overcrowding, so even though I brushed my teeth like I was supposed to, I still got really bad gingivitis and cavities because my standard toothbrush was unable to reach certain places, and I also brushed way too hard.My dental hygienist suggested I get this and I love it! My gums look great, my teeth always feel like I just came from the dentist, it stops when you brush too hard, and it gets in every single place! I went to my orthodontist for the first time after two months of owning this and he said I had super healthy gums and teeth!
  1183. use every day.... recommend.
  1184. better than the vibrating one

  1199. I've owned three different Oral-B electric toothbrushes.<br />The 1st was great, but was powered by two AA batteries, and I felt bad going through so many of them over time.<br />I eventually upgraded to my 2nd Oral-B electric toothbrush - with a rechargeable battery, yay! - but it had an LED screen in the handle which was kind of unnecessary, caused it to be bulky, and I think it also ate up power.<br />So, after using that one for a few years, I finally upgraded to my 3rd Oral-B - this one, the PRO 1000 - which is just right! No unnecessary extras which I'll never use, and which drain power. An easy-to-hold handle. An easy recharger, which gives me a week's worth of brushing. (!) And as if all that weren't enough? This toothbrush is one of the most inexpensive ones!<br />Needless to say… it's already my favorite Oral-B.

Seeing as I am now really &#34;into&#34; obsessive brushing and compulsive flossing, this little number is a godsend. Price is great, it has a lot of power to blast those unsightly bits of animal tendon and pesky escargot tails from betwixt your newly polished fangs. Werewolves might require something of more industrial strength, but this is a MUST for those humans who really don't want their teeth to slowly rot right out of their very heads in a gruesome, yellowing spiral of abject decay. Highly recommended. Nothing like a squeaky clean mouth.

I don't usually have problems with my teeth or gums and dentist has always said my teeth were in very good shape. I have been using this for about a week and it works just as well. The 30 sec timer on it for each area of mouth (4 quadrants 30 sec each) is somewhat noticeable, but not much.<br /><br />I don't go by the 3 month rule. My other brush (oral b spinbrush) had the same rule about changing heads, but I let mine go for almost 6 months and never had a problem with it wearing down or teeth and gums not getting cleaned, so I am hoping this will last as long. I think the 3 month thing is just more of a way to get people to buy brush heads more often then they need to make more money. So only buy when you feel it is necessary (teeth and gums not getting as clean as they should) or you really notice the brush heads wearing out.

  1225. I bought another Oral B toothbrush because the previous one worked well for a few years and mostly because I had recently paid their outrageous price to get a packet of replacement brushes and thus had to buy the same brand to get a handle to which they would attach. This machine runs at a higher speed than the previous model, which attribute I don't really understand. The machine stops if it hits a little friction in my mouth (they previous one never did that). Minor points, I suppose. The major drawback is that there is a blinking green light that lights a darkened bathroom very well for about 15 minutes after using the machine and placing it on the charger. So, if i brush my teeth before going to bed, the annoying green light in the adjoining bathroom flashes on and off onto my bedroom wall until the mechanism is fully charged again. Is it necessary to be told the machine is charging? The older model just showed a dim, steady light to indicate it was working properly. Yes, I could close the bathroom door, but it aids air flow to keep it open. I am going to run a band of electrician's tape around the handle to cover the light. But why should I have to do that?

The new one is better, but not up to the published claims they make about time between charges.<br /><br />However, I believe that this product overall is a critical part of my regimen, and a manual brush or something cheaper would mess with success. I have basically beaten back periodontal disease, such that there is no change for many years now.   1271. I purchased this based on the review on The Wirecutter and I'm glad I followed their advice.<br /><br />Let's be honest: it's a toothbrush. It doesn't need a ton of special features, it just needs to get your teeth clean. And this does the job. As the review on The Wirecutter mentions, and as confirmed with a simple search, the sonic toothbrushes are really just a marketing gimmick and all the extra cleaning options don't really add any true benefit.<br /><br />Having used it for a few months now, I have no regrets. It has a small, powerful head that allows you to reach all areas of your mouth. Unlike some weaker brushes, I can feel that this is really getting my teeth clean. It has a very indiscreet &#34;skip&#34; in the vibration every 30 seconds, with a &#34;double skip&#34; at two minutes to help you ensure a proper brushing time. This feature alone makes this brush worth the purchase over simple brushes. I'm sure I often got impatient when brushing with simple brushes and stopped brushing too quickly without some guide to gently remind you that you need to brush for two minutes. I focus on a quarter of my teeth for each 30 seconds and then move on. I've actually noticed a difference in the feel and look of my teeth after using this brush.<br /><br />The charging base is also easy to use. The brush sits on top of the base and charges wirelessly. The base is concave and ends up getting a little gunky no matter how clean I think my brush is after use, but it's simple to clean.<br /><br />Overall, after my research, I decided this brush offered the best value without going overboard on silly features. I also have no doubts about it's quality: it's a Braun brush made in Germany and I plan on having it for a long time.

  1293. I had a previous version of this brush from around 2003-2004, and it was still going strong...except the brush heads started to fit loosely (i.e. they would fall off if I turned the brush upside down). Surprisingly, I was still able to brush fairly well, and the rechargeable battery still worked fine.<br /><br />Finally decided to replace the thing when I saw the price on this new one (plus $15 off from a mfg rebate). A new version for $30? Sign me up. I was additionally pleased that the Oral-B/Braun folks still use the same size charger -- I set the new brush on the old charger and it started charging immediately (I like the old charger because it has a brush-head holder attached). Nice to think a company out there doesn't obsolete a perfectly good induction charging system just because it is a decade (or more) old. So, now I have a spare charger in case I would need it for some reason (it is more compact, so if I traveled for a long time, it would be nice to have around...)<br /><br />I am not sure how many vibrations/rotations my old brush had, but this one feels like there is more motion overall. The oscillations are still very &#34;tight&#34;, and (obviously) the brush heads fit perfectly and snugly now (brush heads that worked on the old brush all work on this new brush, another nice thing for them to have left alone!).

In my last vacation I tried to use the charger with a 220 to 110 volt converter and the charger got damaged even with converter. Just be aware of this weak point and go for it.   1387. We purchased the version sold by Costco in pairs, and were immediately turned into big Oral-B fans. The kids got one for Christmas, and the parents came next. (My wife charges more frequently, and her's is just fine.)<br /><br />So, what to do?<br /><br />Buying another Costco pair seemed wasteful, since the wife's is still working well; so, I started shopping around for a single unit. I discovered there are actually various versions of this product, but figuring out what was worth what was impossible.<br /><br />Oral-B needs to make versions feature comparison shopping easier.<br /><br />So, I rolled the dice, and went cheapest-I-could-find. One handset, this one, not fancy-anything. A rebate made it an even better deal.<br /><br />This model is lighter, smaller, less noisy, and seems to run smoother and faster than the Costco version (or maybe it's just newer?). But it also feels a bit \\"cheaper\\", and the light blue color isn't attractive.<br /><br />Sometimes I care a lot that an item is cheaper-built, and sometimes I am glad I saved a few dollars. In this case, I am happy I went with the cheaper model and saved money.<br /><br />I definitely don't need the extra features offered in the higher end versions. Definitely.<br /><br />Quality-wise, let's face it, any battery will eventually die, and these devices unforgivably do NOT allow for a replacement. If this device could be upgraded with a new battery, a superior-quality build would make sense. But this product is pre-destined to be discarded after a couple/three years, so why pretend it needs more build quality than is necessary for a throw-away consumer item? And I already mentioned that the fancy features of the higher end models make no sense to me.<br /><br />I won't go off on why Oral-B should be more environmentally responsible... and should make this device's battery upgrade-able.. but, given that corporate environmental irresponsibility is ubiquitous and typical, I am glad I spent less and still have a good way to take care of the ol' pearly whites.nd should make this device's battery upgrade-able.. but, given that corporate environmental irresponsibility is ubiquitous and typical, I am glad I spent less and still have a good way to take care of the ol' pearly whites.

  1438. My wife purchased this for me from Amazon for Christmas because my previous Oral-B of 10 years cratered, so technically I am a verified buyer but it was under her account and she doesn't do reviews.<br /><br />This is what I expect from a rechargeable toothbrush:<br />1) plug unit in to recharge<br />2) attach head<br />3) Brush teeth<br /><br />Pretty simple right? WRONG<br /><br />This is the new age of \\"SMART PRODUCTS\\":<br />1) People are stupid<br />2) People don't know how to recharge a toothbrush<br />3) People don't know how to brush their teeth<br />4) People press too hard when brushing.<br />5) People need to be told where and how long to brush<br /><br />So, as a previous Oral-b user I expect the brush to work the same way my previous brush which lasted 10 years to work. WRONG AGAIN! Since companies can't come up with any new ideas, they start to try and complicate old ones to make them seem new.<br /><br />So after I wait for the little light to stop flashing (indicating unit is charging because people like to set and watch little flashy lights for hours) which I suppose is much better than waiting for a simple solid green light to come on. I finally get the opportunity to brush my teeth. Remember, all you should have to do is charge and brush. So I am brushing and then about a half a minute the thing makes this godawful stutter then starts back up again. Then 30 seconds later it does it again. I wondered if I got a defective unit so I whip out the owner's guide and after going through 3 pages of cautions, I finally get to the operations part.<br /><br />You see we are too stupid and need a \\"SMART SENSE\\" toothbrush to tell us that every 30 seconds you need to focus on another of the 4 quadrants of your month to brush (Total of 2 minutes brushing time). It's like Chinese Water Torture anticipating when that next jolt is going to occur. And if you have to spit before the next jolt, you are just out of luck, because if you turn it off to spit (if you don't you get splattered with toothpaste spit removing it from your month while on) it remembers where you were and when you turn it back on... \\"ZAP\\" it gets you again.<br /><br />One other thing and I will stop ranting. They made the on/off button harder to distinguish in the handle. There you are, trying to turn it off so you can spit (spit seems to be such a gross word) fumbling around the handling, pushing what you think is the button, meanwhile your mouth is filling up with spit and you are afraid to take it out while running or you will get splatter. As the spit starts running down your chin, you finally find the on/off button.<br /><br />Bottom-line:<br />1) Toothbrush cleans your teeth so I don't want to discourage anyone from buying this product.<br />2) I agree that you should brush all your teeth for a minimal of 2 minutes of total brushing time but the 30 Sec timer should be removed or the consumer given the option of disabling it.<br />3) Better On/Off Button<br />4) Oral-B could have made a simpler brush. To me, this timer is just something else that will break down after a short period.you get splattered with toothpaste spit removing it from your month while on) it remembers where you were and when you turn it back on... \\"ZAP\\" it gets you again.<br /><br />One other thing and I will stop ranting. They made the on/off button harder to distinguish in the handle. There you are, trying to turn it off so you can spit (spit seems to be such a gross word) fumbling around the handling, pushing what you think is the button, meanwhile your mouth is filling up with spit and you are afraid to take it out while running or you will get splatter. As the spit starts running down your chin, you finally find the on/off button.<br /><br />Bottom-line:<br />1) Toothbrush cleans your teeth so I don't want to discourage anyone from buying this product.<br />2) I agree that you should brush all your teeth for a minimal of 2 minutes of total brushing time but the 30 Sec timer should be removed or the consumer given the option of disabling it.<br />3) Better On/Off Button<br />4) Oral-B could have made a simpler brush. To me, this timer is just something else that will break down after a short period.

  1444. This was ordered as a replacement for an Oral-B Braun electric toothbrush I purchased almost 20 years ago. I hope this one lasts as long as the one its replacing. This unit has improvements and additional features from the old one. In addition to the oscillating action of the brush head, that comfortably and cleans each tooth, this model also now has a pulsating action and is an improvement over the 20 year old model. This pulsating is timed to signal every 30 seconds to properly time the amount of time cleaning each quadrant of the mouth. A good improvement of an already very good electric toothbrush.   1468. Ok, so the toothbrush itself probably deserves more than one star--it works fine, brushes nicely when you push the button, etc. What has made me very upset about this whole experience is the rebate. It meets U.S. code's definition of mail fraud--\\"having devised or intending to devise a scheme to defraud....use of the mail for the purpose of executing, or attempting to execute, the scheme.\\"<br /><br />I put great care into sending an Amazon receipt, the properly filled out rebate form, and the original UPC from the toothbrush in a VERY well-sealed (tape reinforced) envelope.<br />I get a letter back saying the rebate request is incomplete because they did not receive an original UPC--can I please send it. Ok, so what happens when I send in a photocopy (since I, of course, no longer have the original UPC?) You guessed it. They can't use a photocopy.<br />This same EXACT story has happened to a friend of mine who recently purchased this toothbrush. She got the exact same rejection letter (after sending away the original UPC in a carefully sealed envelope.)<br /><br />It doesn't bother me so much to have lost $20. What bothers me is that Proctor and Gamble has the balls to open rebate letters, toss UPC's in the trash, and send out rejection letters. And that they get away with it. Because the customer has no recourse--they no longer have the original UPC.<br /><br />I certainly don't have recourse...I can't prove I ever sent an original UPC in to them now, can I? A photocopy can be from anything. But I can warn others. Don't assume you'll get the rebate because you jumped through all the right hoops and sent in the right stuff. You quite possibly wont.

  1505. I received this product as part of Amazon's Vine Voice program. I say this because I've never really been keen on spending nearly fifty dollars for a toothbrush, regardless of how \\"professional\\" it is or whatever \\"precision\\" it can claim to have. Raised in a struggling home, I was always taught that a little elbow grease can more than make up for a lot of what you lack otherwise. \\"I got a professional electric toothbrush,\\" I told my dad. \\"Yeah?\\" he said. \\"Why don't you just brush a little harder with the regular kind?\\"<br /><br />This toothbrush does everything that it claims to. My teeth felt sparkling clean after most uses, although I found that the heads seemed to fray and wear out a bit faster than the product claimed they would. Also I have a fairly large mouth with fairly large teeth, and the tiny heads on this thing made it feel like I was brushing with a bundle of soft toothpicks. I suppose that's where the \\"precision\\" comes into play -- it was far easier to get in all the crevices and corners than with a standard toothbrush -- but it also meant I found myself more than once clanging the plastic edge of the head against my enamel.<br /><br />The charge also seems to take awhile, although this is an issue that I had mainly because my bathroom doesn't really have any outlets, so I had to charge the toothbrush in a separate room. Leaving it in the bathroom meant that it ran out of juice faster than normal.<br /><br />It's a good product, does what it claims, and when used as directed, it might be worth the expense for those who can't seem to get a good, thorough cleaning with those old-fashioned manual models. People with teeth the size of [[ASIN:B0015DAEHK Chiclets]], though, might want to look elsewhere.

  1522. The 3D brush head works great. I get much better removal of tartar with this electric toothbrush than by hand brushing. Definitely worth the money for improved gum health. Note that the cheapest model that can use a 3D brush head works just as well as the most expensive model, which just has a few more bells and whistles on the timer and display. No need to buy the more expensive toothbrush. But, the base is poorly designed. Even though I wash the brush after use, toothpaste deposits build up on the top of the charging unit and these smell after a week or two. I have to keep washing the charger unit. The battery doesn't charge well after about 2 years, and youll have to replace the unit. The new oner will seem much stronger as it will hold a good charge. Also, on two different occasions I bought an oral B electric tooth brush and submitted my receipt to Braun, who promised a $20 refund. On both occasions, I never heard back from them--what a scam.
  1523. The toothbrush arrived 2 days after I ordered it. The usual brilliant Amazon service.<br />And I am very pleased with it the brush itself It is the most comfortable electric toothbrush I have used as it is no struggle to get around the back teeth.<br />Light and easy to hold. I have used hard bristle toothbrushes in the past, but this one seemed much harder.   1601. **EDIT March 2014**<br /><br />After one and a half years, the battery seems to be getting worse over time. Despite following the charging instructions and recommendations provided by the manufacturer, there seems to be a disconnect between the battery indicating \\"low\\" vs. the battery depletion time. After the last few charging cycles, I have noticed that the unit will not indicate that the battery is low and needs to be recharged. However, the next brushing cycle will abruptly end after about a minute and THEN indicates that the battery is low and must be charged. Pressing the power button will not turn the unit back on. Hence, I now have to feel out when the battery may be getting low or just charge it every day, rather than once a week or when the unit indicates a low battery. Technically, it is still under warranty, but the shipping cost is on me, making it more worthwhile to just continue using the product as-is or buy a newer model. I am still somewhat happy with the unit, but I will definitely keep this in mind when buying another electric toothbrush in the future.<br /><br />--Previous review--<br /><br />I have used a manual toothbrush for at least the past 10 years, but was looking for a cheap and effective electric one, since I always read about the benefits of them. After using this one, I would be happy to recommend this to others.<br /><br />Positive:<br />-Good size<br />-Mouth feels very clean after use<br />-Replacement heads are available from both the company and generic (so hidden cost of the heads can be reduced if you shop around)<br />-Different heads available for purchase<br />-A single charge lasts about a week when brushing 2x per day<br />-Built-in timer w/ vibration helps gauge how long you've been brushing<br /><br />Negative:<br />-Wish it would charge a little faster. Minor complaint, but if I brush at 7AM and get the low battery warning, I plug it in. Indicator still shows charging even if I wait until 11PM that night, and I like to let it charge fully, so I use a manual toothbrush for that session until the following morning, and then it is fully charged.<br /><br />Final verdict: a good electric toothbrush at a reasonable price. If you're not looking to buy the top-end products at top-end prices, but want to see what electric toothbrushes are all about, try this one out.let it charge fully, so I use a manual toothbrush for that session until the following morning, and then it is fully charged.<br /><br />Final verdict: a good electric toothbrush at a reasonable price. If you're not looking to buy the top-end products at top-end prices, but want to see what electric toothbrushes are all about, try this one out.
  1602. Good quality and efficient
  1603. Works as well as all the Oral-B toothbrushes I've used in the past. They're pretty consistent in quality.
  1604. I started with an Oral-B toothbrush, then bought a Sonicare. I'm back to Oral-B. First and foremost, the Oral-B brush is a solid piece, not the contraption Sonicare sells that allows stinky mold and bacteria to proliferate at the brush base and beneath the cone where it screws into the base. The Sonicare cleaning action was fine; it was the unsanitary design, the really nasty smell, the need to take the brush assembly apart at least every week and figure out a way to swab out all that gunk under it without corroding the metal parts that was so off-putting. The Oral-B brush, on the other hand, has one connecting point and a ring that seals very well. The price of the brushes is another win for Oral-B...at least $4 cheaper than Sonicare per brush. The vibration of the Oral-B is a bit noisier and there's more of it. But who cares? It cleans well, cleans up easily and is a much cheaper way to get the job done. Because it's slimmer, I find it much easier to navigate around my mouth and keep the base dry as well.
  1605. It works well and is comfortable to use. I wish it were a bit more powerful (more rotations per minute) but for $40 it's a decent buy.
  1606. I've just upgraded from the $20 version of the Oral B Rechargeable Electric toothbrush. I didn't think I would care that I get a reminder to change quandrants, but it is really helpful.
