The $20 version would not let you know that it was going to die, it would just die in the middle of a brushing. I simply left it plugged in all the time. The 1000 will flash red to let you know that it needs to be recharged. Awesome. It flashes red when I'm done brushing. I plug it in. The next time I brush my teeth I unplug it. A charge lasts several days. I like the brushing action. My teeth feel great. I use a sensitive brush and my teeth feel clean and there is no pain.

And AFAIK there is absolutely no way to disable it. For those who didn't know, after 30 seconds it pauses once for 1 second, after 60 seconds it pauses twice, and after 2 min it pauses 3 times.. or something like that. I don't brush for a set length of time, I carefully get each side of each tooth. So I do not need any timer feature, and the stuttering is just really, really annoying. I wish it could just beep or have an LED light up or something.

Both have indicators show the amount of use. It is recommended that the brush heads be replaced every three months or when the indicators are half way faded. Because of the way I use this toothbrush (not all the time) I have not had to replace the heads more than once in the past year.<br /><br />One difference between the sonic toothbrush and this one is that this one stops spinning if too much pressure is applied.<br /><br />The charging station has a small footprint which is very helpful for the old fashioned lavatory I have at the office which has very little space for items kept constantly available.<br /><br />The cleaning experience between the sonic toothbrush and this one is not much different. My newest Oral-B does as fine a job of cleaning as its predecessors did. In contrast to other rechargeable electric toothbrushes, the Oral-B has a smaller, round head which more readily allows it to access ALL areas of my teeth. In my pre-Oral-B days I needed to visit my dentist every 4 months for teeth cleaning because of a problem I had with plaque buildup on the back of my bottom front teeth. Once I began using an Oral-B, no more plaque problem! I've been able to save money because now I see the dentist only twice a year instead of three times a year for regular check-ups. There's a feature with this Oral-B that didn't exist with my previous ones -- while operating, it is programmed to hesitate for a couple of second every couple of minutes, as a cue to the length of time that a quadrant of your mouth should be brushed. I find the hesitation to be a bit annoying and unnecessary, but I guess that feature is aimed at kids. All in all, a fine product that I'd highly recommend.

  1735. Bought it because I have tooth sensitivity and have a root canal done in the past.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-cheap-ish (Target sold these for 39 bucks for a while)<br />-different brush head designs available (over half a dozen) for different cleaning styles (also a con)<br />-rechargeable<br />-cleans better than manual brushes<br /><br />Cons:<br />-instructions are vague and in broken English, still can't figure out how to toggle between the different speed settings--or there just isn't any difference. Allegedly there is a sensitive teeth setting, doesn't seem any different from the other two (whitening and regular). For that matter, what is a whitening setting?<br />-takes forever (over a day) to charge, doesn't hold charge \\"about a week\\" as stated<br />-different brush heads are all essentially the same, except for the flossing one which actually works pretty good<br />-pressure cutoff doesn't really work, claims to stop brushing if you push too hard. I pushed the brush head against my thumb with some considerable force, much more than any sane person would do when brushing and couldn't get it to disengage.<br />-\\"stutters\\" meant to get you to switch to another quadrant are annoying, and can't be turned off<br /><br />In short:<br />You can get a rechargeable toothbrush that uses the same heads for half the price at most grocery stores (either Oral-B or a generic brand) that doesn't have all of these useless upgrades.
  1736. Update: I never got back to this but two of us bought one of these on the basis of a rebate and neither of us ever received the rebate. The battery is now starting to need to be recharged noticeably more often now, so expect the life of one of these to last 3-4 years, which might not be as long as you expected it to last. I have a personal policy that when I get screwed over on a rebate, I do my best to not buy items from the same company again. While it might be difficult to avoid all Proctor and Gamble products, I will avoid Oral B products from now on, just as I avoid medicines from Abbott Pharmaceuticals after they screwed me over on a rebate for a blood glucose monitor. I figure that they'll lose a lot more money on me than they gained by screwing me on a rebate.<br /><br />This electric toothbrush works very well. No gimmicks, it just works. It's the one recommended to me by my dental hygienist.<br /><br />Every 30 seconds for the 2-minute standard timing for brushing your teeth, it vibrates differently to let you now it's time to move on to the next quadrant in your mouth. You can stop the brush at that point to add more toothpaste (I use baking soda myself) and press it again. It remembers where you are in the time cycle unless you leave it off for a couple of minutes, when it will reset itself.<br /><br />It takes a long time to charge up fully the first time, but that's a good thing since the charger is not forcing a lot of current into the battery. You can store it on the charging base or elsewhere. It will need another charge in about a week. Every several months you should completely discharge the battery then recharge it according to the instructions. You may find that not keeping it on the charging base and just charging it when it runs down may provide a longer battery life.<br /><br />The battery appears to not be replaceable, but you can remove it when it's time to dispose of the product so you can recycle it properly.<br /><br />This product came with a plastic travel case, which I may use infrequently, but it's nice to have something to protect it. There are generic brush heads available. I haven't tried any of these yet, but I have read that some generic brush heads do not last and break. Some work, others don't, and you can have a mix of these in a batch if you buy them from online auction sites. If you buy them from Amazon, you can return them if you find them to be defective or are otherwise not satisfied.<br /><br />The brushes have some bristles with a tint that fades over time to let you know when it's time to replace it. I think it's more of a marketing tool to get you to buy replacement heads more often, but you can use that as a reminder if you prefer. I will replace mine when it feels too soft.<br /><br />You can buy a few different types of brush heads for this device. The user guide shows which ones you can buy and what each one's purpose is.<br /><br />The brush heads have a colored ring between the head and handle so you can tell one from another if more than two people in a household use the same product. The downside is that when you buy the product, you have no way of knowing which color of ring is in the package. We bought two of them and fortunately they had different colors to tell them apart. The replacement heads, if you buy them in a multi-pack, have different colored rings, so if you buy one of those packs when you buy the product, you will probably have several colors to choose from. Alternatively, you would color one ring with fingernail polish and let it dry before putting it on a brush head, or just use some colored tape around one or more of them in your bathroom. You could even make a label for each handle with the user's name on it.<br /><br />Overall, this is much better than the inexpensive ones I've had in the past. I will definitely brush my teeth more often now that it's so easy to do. Easy to do? How hard can it be to brush your teeth with a regular toothbrush?<br /><br/>You have to try one of these to understand. I tend to brush too quickly, and this device helps me time how long I brush in each quarter of my mouth. Sure, I could set a timer and keep an eye on it, switching to different parts of my mouth as the timer counts down, but this is very convenient. It also probably does a better job without brushing too hard.<br /><br />Oral B (made by Braun) makes different models that use the same brush heads. This model is great. I haven't tried the others, but they are likely well made, like other products I've had made by Braun.<br /><br />If you found this review helpful, please click the YES button below this review. Thanks!!!e time how long I brush in each quarter of my mouth. Sure, I could set a timer and keep an eye on it, switching to different parts of my mouth as the timer counts down, but this is very convenient. It also probably does a better job without brushing too hard. Oral B (made by Braun) makes different models that use the same brush heads. This model is great. I haven't tried the others, but they are likely well made, like other products I've had made by Braun. If you found this review helpful, please click the YES button below this review. Thanks!!!

  1745. I've had two other Oral-B Electric toothbrushes in the past. So when my last one died I decided to, of course, buy a new one. First my Pros and Cons list:<br /><br />PROS:<br />Strong vibrations from the brush head<br />Reasonably priced<br /><br />CONS:<br />Handle is a little narrow<br />Base is just a little bigger than the bottom of the toothbrush bottom<br />Wish there was a little more rubber grip on handle<br />Power button is a bit small<br /><br />REVIEW:<br />Even though I had more cons than pros, don't get me wrong, I still really like this toothbrush. I am just nitpicking little details I wish could be improved on. For example, I wish the handle was a little thicker just so it could fit nicely into my hand. My two previous electric Oral-B toothbrushes has a nice feel in my hand size-wise. Also, a little more rubber for the grip would improve comfort and, of course, grip while using the brush.<br />The power button also was a little small and hard. This can make it a little difficult turning the toothbrush on and off. Sometimes my thumb is pressing several times trying to find the power button. Nitpicking, but it is a little annoying.<br />The base is little narrow so it feels like you can easily tip it over or knock your brush off the base. My previous models had a backing so at least it felt more secure. Maybe some people like the small footprint of the base. So it could just be me.<br /><br />Overall, I still really like my brush and I still would recommend it. I do like the powerful vibrations of the brush head, maybe even stronger than my old ones. It feels like it does a good job cleaning my teeth, which is all that matters anyway. And since it is reasonably priced, I am happy.

  1776. So I think this is a good basic electric toothbrush. The head is tiny so it fits on each tooth and only takes a drop of toothpaste. It vibrates strongly, which I'm still trying to get used to. My skull vibrates and my eyeballs vibrate with it and it's a weird uncomfortable feeling. I found it doesn't reduce the need to floss even a little bit. It seems to clean the surfaces very well. But when I floss afterwards, it's amazing how much stuff still comes out from between the teeth. So it may be beneficial to use an electric toothbrush but if you do a good job on each tooth with a plain old manual toothbrush, I would probably save my money.

This is when we got our third one (reviewed here). I'm an engineer and am just fascinated that you can make a consumer electronics device like this that runs for 15 years--amazing. (JPL needs to open one of these up.) The other thing I like is that the charger interface is exactly the same as it was on our original one from 15 years ago. We have one charger on the vanity. One of the brushes is always sitting in the charger and they get swapped every 3 or 4 days. The newer charger (a tiny thing) sits in the travel bag. Anyway, I'm a fan. It cleans teeth too.
